[04:24:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
hsivonen: I notice that Hixie's "microsyntaxes-dates" folder is empty but the v.nu behavior for checking "valid date or time string" and "global date and time string" is still not conformant

[04:25:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
specifically, I notice that for date-or-time, v.nu allows, e.g., 1996-01-01T12:05:25 (a date and time with no time-zone information) and 12:05:25Z (a time with no date but with time-zone information)

[04:25:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
but the spec prohibits both of those

[04:26:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
and for global-date-and-time, the spec allows 1996-01-01T12:05Z (a date and time string with no seconds specified), but v.nu prohibits it

[04:37:00.0000] <zcorpan>
i thought v.nu didn't implement the spec but just used an off-the-shelf library for validating dates and times

[04:41:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[05:00:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
hsivonen: btw, I also noticed today that for cases of a time element that has a pubdate attribute, the spec now requires the datetime value can't be just a time

[05:00:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
that is, it must either be a date with a time, or just a date

[05:01:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
so I checked in a change for that today

[05:01:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
but the spec also makes the same requirement for the text content of the time element, if no datetime attribute is specified

[05:02:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
so I can make a change for that too, but I'm wondering if it's worth it, especially given that there seems to be some chance of the time element just being dropped altogether

[06:26:00.0000] <brucel>
zcorpan "Hixie: i don't mind dropping <datalist>-fallback-to-<select>. most authors use script to implement fallback instead of clever markup" - surely too early to tell? datalist so far has ben implemented in Opera for a while, Chrome recently. So a bit premature to declare the fallback mechanism dead?

[06:27:00.0000] <Ms2ger>
And Firefox for a while

[06:27:01.0000] <Ms2ger>
Don't forget the best implementation in the world ;)

[06:27:02.0000] <jgraham>
/me thinks the fallback is a good idea still. Was there some evidence it isn't

[06:28:00.0000] <annevk>
The fallback mechanism was mostly designed for a time when browsers were not updated

[06:28:01.0000] <jgraham>
?

[06:28:02.0000] <annevk>
Well, IE was not updated

[06:28:03.0000] <jgraham>
That's not evidence it isn't

[06:28:04.0000] <annevk>
That changed and scripts became more prevalent to handle fallback in better ways

[06:28:05.0000] <annevk>
So these days introducing somewhat cleaner design is feasible

[06:29:00.0000] <jgraham>
That sounds a bit like "backwards compatibility is hard. Let's not bother"

[06:29:01.0000] <jgraham>
Or "graceful degradation" if you like

[06:29:02.0000] <annevk>
It's more that backwards compatibility is solved in a different way that allows new features to be designed without clutter

[06:33:00.0000] <jgraham>
What is the clutter in this case? And who does it help if it is already implemented everywhere?

[06:34:00.0000] <annevk>
new implementors, people trying to grasp the platform

[06:34:01.0000] <annevk>
i value those more than legacy implementations

[06:35:00.0000] <jgraham>
Is there any evidence that this is actually hard to implement?

[06:37:00.0000] <annevk>
it's pretty clear it's more complex

[06:37:01.0000] <brucel>
It seems to me that "everything inside datalist is invisible, except the <options>" is beautifully simple, annevk

[06:38:00.0000] <brucel>
(even I understand it)

[06:38:01.0000] <annevk>
brucel, except that doesn't tell you if you need to traverse children or descendants, whether scripts are executed, whether other descendants are submitted, etc.

[06:39:00.0000] <zcorpan>
brucel: maybe, although i base my judgement on other features where i see most authors use script to implement the fallback behavior

[06:40:00.0000] <zcorpan>
brucel: which makes sense since it's dead simple if somebody else writes the script, e.g. modernizr

[06:41:00.0000] <zcorpan>
jgraham: i recall bratell whining about datalist having to consider all descendants and not just the children

[06:42:00.0000] <zcorpan>
it complicates teh implementation

[06:42:01.0000] <brucel>
zcorpan and that's legit  - but how big is the amount of evidence at the moment? Basing it on the decisions of a small group of highly-motivated script-savvy early adopters isn't indicative of the majority of authors who, let's face it, won't be figuring this stuff out until IE10

[06:43:00.0000] <zcorpan>
brucel: the fallback is *for* early adopters. when it's mainstream, you don't bother with fallback at all

[06:44:00.0000] <zcorpan>
if the early adopters don't use the declarative fallback mechanism, it isn't going to do anyone any good

[06:47:00.0000] <brucel>
zcorpan I don't understand you, sorry. The fallback, surely, is so IE6,7,8,9 users get an input mechanism more helpful than a plain text input.

[06:48:00.0000] <zcorpan>
i'm saying that pages that use datalist will use a scripted dropdown if datalist is not supported

[06:48:01.0000] <zcorpan>
if (!input.list) { use jquery dropdown and be done with it }

[06:51:00.0000] <brucel>
feels to me like losing a useful declarative fallback mechanism in order to make it easier for implementors, because in the short time that it's been supported by majority of browsers, not everyone is using it

[06:54:00.0000] <zcorpan>
yeah

[06:55:00.0000] <zcorpan>
i've been disappointed several times where new features have useful fallback mechanisms but people feature check for the feature instead and fallback to jquery or something with script

[06:55:01.0000] <Rik`>

[13:51:00.0000] <jgraham>

[13:52:01.0000] <Hixie>

[14:34:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[14:42:00.0000] <Philip`>
Rather than proving hard optimisations are perfectly safe and coping with obscure edge cases, browsers ought to run an aggressive optimiser that's safe 99% of the time, and also run a completely independent clone of the page in parallel with a slow but perfectly safe JS engine

[14:43:00.0000] <Philip`>
then if the first one happens to go wrong, the divergence will be detected soon when the second one catches up with it, and the browser can switch to displaying the output of the second one

[14:43:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
And then stay on the slow one forever?

[14:43:02.0000] <Philip`>
so you'll eventually end up with the correct result but in most cases you'll get the result displayed much sooner

[14:44:00.0000] <Philip`>
It's a foolproof plan

[14:44:01.0000] <Hixie>
there's one pretty fatal flaw with this plan

[14:45:00.0000] <Hixie>
no wait, two.

[14:45:01.0000] <Hixie>
though i guess the second one is the same as the first.

[14:45:02.0000] <Hixie>
so one.

[14:45:03.0000] <Hixie>
(namely, that script can have side-effects)

[14:46:00.0000] <Hixie>
(the second one is that the script's side-effects include "taking time" which can be detected from script, but i guess you cuold make new Date() in the second script always return whatever it returned on that occurrence in the first script.)

[14:52:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[18:16:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Okay, MathML only collides with "<image>".

[18:16:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
SVG collides with <a>, <font>, <image>, <script>, <style>, and <title>.

[18:17:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
<a>, <script>, and <style> should just unify; that's pretty easy to argue.

[18:18:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
<image> is roughly the same.  Unification is possible.

[18:19:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
<font> and <title> very clearly can't unify.

[18:19:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Darn.

[18:20:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
MathML's <image> is completely different.

[18:21:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Possibly SVG2 could switch to <img>, leaving <image> for MathML.

[18:21:01.0000] <heycam>
well

[18:21:02.0000] <TabAtkins>

[18:21:03.0000] <heycam>

[18:22:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[03:26:02.0000] <Zeddy>

[10:27:04.0000] <zewt>

[10:28:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[10:28:03.0000] <annevk>

[10:28:04.0000] <jgraham>

[10:29:00.0000] <zewt>

[10:29:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[10:29:02.0000] <dglazkov>
annevk: ok.

[10:29:03.0000] <dglazkov>
:)

[10:29:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
So generally "open" = "awaiting action from Hixie".

[10:30:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
RESOLVED NEEDSINFO is supposed to mean "we can't do anything about this until the reporter answers our questions", but maybe it doesn't convey that very well.

[10:30:01.0000] <jgraham>
zewt: That wan't really my point

[10:30:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
I generally use NEEDSINFO if I think there's some reasonable chance that the reporter will be able to clarify, and WONTFIX if I'm confident that we don't want to fix the bug regardless.

[10:30:03.0000] <Philip`>
AryehGregor: RESOLVED doesn't really convey the impression that the issue is currently unresolved and awaiting further discussion

[10:31:00.0000] <zewt>
"resolved" says "we're done here" to reporters

[10:31:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
No, it doesn't, but I don't configure the W3C bug tracker.

[10:31:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or the HTMLWG policies that say how to use it.

[10:31:03.0000] <manu-db>
yes, the issue is "RESOLVED", AryehGregor

[10:32:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I've sometimes avoided RESOLVED NEEDSINFO and just left the bug open when I'm confident the commenter will actually respond with the info, but I don't do that consistently.

[10:32:01.0000] <Philip`>
If people can agree on changes that would significantly improve matters, I assume it wouldn't be too hard to change the tracker and/or policies to cope with that

[10:32:02.0000] <manu-db>
I'd rather have a bug listed as OPEN NEEDSINFO - or BLOCKED NEEDSINFO

[10:32:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Anyway, please do feel free to reopen any of the bugs if you feel you have further information to provide, regardless of what RESOLVED sounds like it means.

[10:32:04.0000] <Philip`>
so it's probably a useful discussion

[10:33:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I do agree with your point about the demoralizing effect of the terminology here, but you'd have to complain to MikeSmith or someone about that, I can't add new options for what I can do to bugs.

[10:33:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Anyway, I'm not going to be doing much bug-resolving anymore, it's taking away too much time from spec editing.

[10:35:00.0000] <manu-db>
It's not necessarily demoralizing for me, AryehGregor - but it really did sound like you were just closing the bug and not listening (I forgot which one precisely), but if you hadn't told me your intent - my base assumption is that you're not interested at all in addressing the concern.

[10:36:00.0000] <manu-db>
that's what RESOLVED means to me...

[10:36:01.0000] <manu-db>
I'll go back and review when I have some time and attempt to explain in more detail.

[10:36:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Generally when I close NEEDSINFO I say something like "I don't understand, please explain X".  If I close WONTFIX, then yes, I'm basically saying I think I understand what you're saying and I disagree and I don't think you're going to get me to agree.

[10:36:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
(but you're still welcome to try)

[13:20:00.0000] <Hixie>
cross-site scripting is essentially when you don't escape user input in html; sql injection is the same with sql; what do you call the similar thing where you don't validate user input on the server and so allow out-of-bounds input to be stored in the db?

[13:20:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hixie, "not a vulnerability by itself

[13:20:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
"

[13:21:00.0000] <timeless>
lol

[13:21:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
MediaWiki, for instance, doesn't escape anything before storing in the DB, as a rule.

[13:21:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
It trusts text content in the DB as untrusted.

[13:21:03.0000] <timeless>
Hixie: failure to enforce boundary constraints

[13:21:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
All escaping is done as close to output time as possible, so it's easy to audit.

[13:21:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's much harder to escape at input time, since input can come from a zillion different places that you have varying degrees of control over.

[13:21:06.0000] <timeless>
AryehGregor: what if there isn't `output` in the normal sense?

[13:21:07.0000] <timeless>
such as a join?

[13:22:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Then what vulnerability is there?

[13:22:01.0000] <Ms2ger>
/nick Robert'); DROP TABLE Students;--

[13:22:02.0000] <Hixie>
i mean like checking that an "age" field is >=0

[13:22:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
By "output" I mean "use".

[13:22:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hixie, store it in the database as an unsigned integer?  :)

[13:22:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
But okay.

[13:22:06.0000] <timeless>
s/0/18/

[13:22:07.0000] <Hixie>

[13:22:08.0000] <timeless>

[13:22:09.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:23:00.0000] <timeless>

[13:23:01.0000] <Hixie>

[13:23:02.0000] <Hixie>

[13:23:03.0000] <timeless>
not everything is cool enough to get a buzzword

[13:25:00.0000] <timeless>
i think `failure to santize <whatever>` is probably the closest to a buzzword, but i'm not sure that matches what you want

[13:25:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I don't know of a way to phrase it positively (without "failing", "not", etc.)

[13:25:02.0000] <timeless>
you can review cwe to see `failure to santize` appearing a bunch of times

[13:25:03.0000] <timeless>
`improper input validation`

[13:25:04.0000] <timeless>
doesn't technically have a negative :)

[13:25:05.0000] <timeless>
that's from CWE-74

[13:26:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
"Input validation" is definitely the term for the thing you should be doing.

[13:26:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
For the thing you shouldn't be doing, "improper input validation" sounds like as good a term as any.

[13:26:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's not an exploit by itself, so it doesn't get a buzzword.

[13:26:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, I guess it can be a minor exploit by itself.

[13:27:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Like if you have maxlength and users can just remove it in their favorite web development tool and submit stuff that's whatever length they want, that might be classified as a security vulnerability, insofar as it involves users doing something with your site that they aren't supposed to be able to.

[13:27:01.0000] <Philip`>
One occasional problem is storing a user's IP address in a database, when you get it from some function that understands X-Forwarded-For, when not running behind a proxy that sets X-Forwarded-For, so malicious users can set it to whatever they want and trick you into storing the wrong IP address

[13:28:00.0000] <Ms2ger>
So, Bert thinks newline normalization in attributes is the biggest problem when parsing HTML with an SGML parser?

[13:28:01.0000] <Philip`>
which is sort of related to storing wrong information in a database, but separate from constraint validation (which any self-respecting SQL database ought to be enforcing automatically)

[13:29:00.0000] <timeless>
Philip`: in theory you're supposed to validate the source against a list of trusted proxies

[13:30:00.0000] <timeless>
Ms2ger: that means bert doesn't think html as sgml has many problems?

[13:30:01.0000] <timeless>
(like Comments or NetTags ?)

[13:30:02.0000] <Philip`>
In practice people forget to do that

[13:30:03.0000] <Ms2ger>
I wouldn't dare to claim I understand Bert

[13:30:04.0000] <timeless>
heh

[13:31:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, Wikipedia was actually hit by a subtle version of that once.

[13:31:01.0000] <timeless>
AryehGregor: nice

[13:31:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Squid did understand X-Forwarded-For and sanitized it, but the PHP variables used to access it treated X_Forwarded_For the same as X-Forwarded-For, and Squid didn't.

[13:31:03.0000] <timeless>
nice

[13:32:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
MediaWiki has a whitelist of trusted XFF providers that it uses, including various major ISPs in addition to its own internal Squids and Varnishes.

[15:05:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[15:06:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[15:06:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[15:07:02.0000] <gsnedders>

[15:07:03.0000] <TabAtkins>

[15:07:04.0000] <TabAtkins>

[15:16:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[15:16:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Means that ::marker is an abspos element using a special positioning scheme.  Abspos elements leave behind a "placeholder" box in their normal position, which is a 0x0 inline element.

[15:17:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Sometimes, if a linebox would only be generated due to a placeholder, CSS suppresses the linebox.

[15:17:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
It's possible that the float is interfering with this.

[02:54:00.0000] <annevk>

[02:55:00.0000] <annevk>

[02:55:01.0000] <annevk>

[10:12:01.0000] <Ms2ger>

[10:13:00.0000] <annevk>

[10:13:01.0000] <smaug____>

[10:13:02.0000] <smaug____>

[10:14:00.0000] <smaug____>

[10:14:01.0000] <leaverou>
because the spec example is copied by tutorials all over and new authors will get the impression that inline event handlers are fine

[10:14:02.0000] <zewt>
it sounds like you're under the impression that they're "evil"

[10:14:03.0000] <leaverou>
so it's indirectly (?) promoting bad practices

[10:14:04.0000] <smaug____>
is it a bad practice?

[10:15:00.0000] <leaverou>
in most cases it is, it violates separation of concerns

[10:16:00.0000] <zewt>
do you want to write 3x as much code for no benefit? heh

[10:17:00.0000] <leaverou>
zewt: are you going to praise the <font> tag next? :)

[10:17:01.0000] <zewt>
sarcasm doesn't lead to convincing arguments

[10:18:00.0000] <leaverou>
and it's hardly 3x as much code, just like presentational HTML over CSS, it's actually less code when repetition is involved

[10:18:01.0000] <leaverou>
also, polluting the global namespace with all these functions is a JS bad practice

[10:18:02.0000] <Ms2ger>

[10:19:00.0000] <zewt>
indeed, meh

[10:19:01.0000] <zewt>

[10:19:02.0000] <leaverou>

[10:20:00.0000] <leaverou>

[10:20:02.0000] <annevk>

[10:20:05.0000] <Philip`>
The HTML spec even has examples with uppercase tags, which I'm sure every sane person in the world thinks is crazy

[10:21:00.0000] <Philip`>
so it's not trying to be a guide to any set of best practices

[10:22:00.0000] <leaverou>
Philip`: that's a good point.

[10:22:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, it has examples with *mixed*-case tags.

[10:22:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
I'm pretty sure it has something like <BloCkquoTE> somewhere.

[10:22:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
The philosophy it adopts is that if something is valid, it wants to use it occasionally in examples so people don't assume it's wrong because they never see it.

[10:23:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
If inline event handlers were always a bad idea, the spec would say they're invalid.

[10:23:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
There's no class of things called "fully conforming but we think they shouldn't be used", that would be silly.

[10:24:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
If we think they shouldn't be used, we should make them at least raise a warning, and if we think it's fine to use them, why not use them in examples?

[10:24:01.0000] <leaverou>
AryehGregor: Ok, that's a valid argument and I agree. Btw, I never said inline event handlers are always bad, just in many cases.

[10:24:02.0000] <karlcow>

[12:53:00.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: when it comes to implementation simplicity, browsers are not the concern.

[12:54:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hixie, what implementers are you worried about that will need to exactly implement this part of HTML but will not need to implement ES as well?

[12:56:00.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: all the off-the-shelf tools? the vast majority of HTML processors don't support ES, nor are they updated frequently.

[12:56:01.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: should we defer to other specs for everything where we happen to be a subset of another spec's algorithms?

[12:56:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hixie, examples?  Ones that need to exactly match how browsers behave?

[12:56:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hixie, I don't propose that the algorithm be a subset, I propose that it be made identical.

[12:56:04.0000] <Hixie>
you want to support Infinity?

[12:56:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
Not just an editorial change, a normative change.

[12:57:00.0000] <Hixie>
you want to support a radix attribute on integer attributes?

[12:57:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Identical with some extra error handling tacked on, okay.

[12:57:02.0000] <Hixie>
subset.

[12:57:03.0000] <Hixie>
or superset, i guess.

[12:57:04.0000] <Hixie>
either way, not identical.

[12:57:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
I already said that it should be the same as parseInt(x, 10), not parseInt(x), so there's no radix issue.

[12:57:06.0000] <Hixie>
that's a subset then.

[12:58:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
And yes, I think that when we have a normative dependency on a spec in practice anyway, we should defer to it where that would make the resulting spec shorter.  In practice we have a normative dependency on ES no matter what, there's no mileage in trying to avoid it.

[12:58:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
But anyway, I posted to whatwg, we'll see what the implementers think.

[12:58:02.0000] <Hixie>
making specs shorter is not a goal.

[12:59:00.0000] <Hixie>
we could make the spec massively shorter, e.g. by dropping all the domintro stuff and introduction sections, all the examples, all the notes

[12:59:01.0000] <Hixie>
every time you have an indirection through anothe spec, it adds significant complexity

[13:00:00.0000] <Hixie>
you have to track the other spec if it changes

[13:00:01.0000] <jgraham>
/me prefers the idea of resusing ES algorithms in general

[13:00:02.0000] <Hixie>
either normatively or just changing the editorial issues like the section or algorithm name

[13:00:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
jgraham, that would be useful to say on whatwg, especially if you're in a position to say whether Opera's willing to do what the spec says.

[13:00:04.0000] <Hixie>
you have to read two specs instead of one

[13:00:05.0000] <Hixie>
etc etc etc.

[13:00:06.0000] <Hixie>
and in this particular case, the ES definition isn't stable, it changes over time

[13:01:00.0000] <Hixie>
which is just plain silly.

[13:01:01.0000] <jgraham>
Not least because there is a non-zero chance that people implementing the feature will just say "oh we have code that does that already" and call that rather than looking for all the subtle differences

[13:01:02.0000] <jgraham>
Which leads to poor interop

[13:01:03.0000] <Hixie>
there's tons of different code to parse integers and floats

[13:01:04.0000] <Hixie>
why should we match ES rather than CSS?

[13:01:05.0000] <Hixie>
or C?

[13:02:00.0000] <jgraham>
In an ideal world HTML and ES and CSS would all match

[13:02:01.0000] <Hixie>
jgraham: the problem you describe is one that validators solve in a hurry.

[13:02:02.0000] <Hixie>
er

[13:02:03.0000] <Hixie>
s/validators/tests/

[13:03:00.0000] <jgraham>
If the problems the tests bring up require lots of new code and only affect edge cases people are unlikley to be in a hurry to fix bugs

[13:03:01.0000] <jgraham>
+those

[13:03:02.0000] <Hixie>
this is not a case that needs lots of new code

[13:03:03.0000] <Hixie>
in fact it requires significantly less code than the ES equivalent

[13:04:00.0000] <Hixie>
and might even require less code than trying to expose the ES function and reference that

[13:04:01.0000] <Hixie>
since there's no guarantee the ES function is actually exposed to other code outside the JS library

[13:04:02.0000] <jgraham>
Well that is true

[13:04:03.0000] <jgraham>
It is also easier to test if the requirements are the same

[13:05:00.0000] <jgraham>
Because you can just reuse the same tests

[13:05:01.0000] <Hixie>
not really

[13:05:02.0000] <Hixie>
how to escape characters is quite different in HTML and JS

[13:06:00.0000] <jgraham>
Well the actual input files will be different. But the range of cases they cover will be identical rather than subtly different

[13:06:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's confusing for authors.

[13:06:02.0000] <Hixie>
the range of cases they cover can still be identical, it's just that the tests for HTML wouldn't change over time, whereas in ES' case the tests need to change every time Unicode is updated

[13:07:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I've seen a case where an author assumed parseInt() would work to translate content attributes to their reflected equivalents.

[13:07:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I think I linked it on the bug.

[13:07:02.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: that is ludicrous, given the difference is in parts of unicode most authors will never even hear about let alone put in a numeric attribute.

[13:07:03.0000] <Hixie>
parseInt() will work fine on conforming content.

[13:07:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yes, the difference is trivial, so it will only fail in bizarre and therefore hard-to-debug corner cases.

[13:07:05.0000] <Hixie>
that's what validators are for.

[13:07:06.0000] <AryehGregor>
On the other hand, since the difference is trivial, there's no reason for it to exist.

[13:07:07.0000] <AryehGregor>
We care about non-conforming content too.  It might be script-generated, too, in which case validators don't help.

[13:08:00.0000] <Hixie>
i've already given half a dozen reasons for the difference to exist, AryehGregor

[13:08:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I've already said why I disagree with all of them.

[13:08:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
No point in arguing further, either implementers are willing to follow your spec or not.

[13:09:00.0000] <Hixie>
you might disagree with the reasons, but that doesn't mean there are no reasons.

[13:10:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
You gave reasons to avoid the normative dependency on ES, not reasons why the HTML algorithm is better than ES's.  Except for the fact that the ES algorithm changes over time, but you said yourself that the changes are only in cases that most authors will never even hear about.

[13:10:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I didn't see you give any other reason why the HTML algorithm is better than the ES one, unless I missed something.

[13:11:00.0000] <Hixie>
the only difference between the two is that the ES one changes over time, no?

[13:12:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
The only one I know of, yes.  Or rather, that they use different whitespace definitions.

[13:12:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
But that difference is not important, because the presence of such whitespace is a corner-case and it only matters that behavior be well-defined, not what it actually is.

[13:13:00.0000] <Hixie>
so there's one difference, and it's got a reason (that you think is unimportant).

[13:13:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Do you think it's important?

[13:13:02.0000] <Hixie>
i think it is important for specs' syntax requirements not to drift over time, yes.

[13:14:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
All specs change over time.

[13:15:00.0000] <Hixie>
and all people eventually die, but that doesn't make death a good thing

is it in a document?

[16:13:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Hm, guess not.

[16:13:02.0000] <annevk>
"When an iframe element is first inserted into a document, the user agent must create a nested browsing context, and then process the iframe attributes for the first time."

[16:13:03.0000] <annevk>
that would explain your problem

[16:14:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[03:03:00.0000] <zcorpan>

[08:18:00.0000] <annevk>
smaug____, should prolly say that while aDoneCallback is running you cannot invoke ModificationBatch methods

[08:19:00.0000] <smaug____>
annevk: why?

[08:20:00.0000] <annevk>
smaug____, what would happen?

[08:20:01.0000] <smaug____>
the "batch" would listen for some new modifications

[08:21:00.0000] <annevk>
I guess that could work

[08:21:01.0000] <annevk>
also, why not have specialized Modification interfaces?

[08:22:00.0000] <smaug____>
for simplicity

[08:22:01.0000] <annevk>
for text / children / attributes

[08:22:02.0000] <smaug____>
and Modification interface is kind of based on current MutationEvent

[08:23:00.0000] <annevk>
I noticed that

[08:26:00.0000] <smaug____>
annevk: can you see something terribly bad in the approach ?

[08:26:01.0000] <smaug____>
it is quite close to other proposals, of course

[08:29:00.0000] <annevk>
the only thing I think is a little weird is that ModificationBatch is also the argument passed to the callback

[08:29:01.0000] <annevk>
what is the 'this' of the callback?

[08:29:02.0000] <annevk>
and what does .modifications return while not in a callback?

[08:30:00.0000] <smaug____>
I thought I said that .modifications is empty while not in callback

[08:30:01.0000] <smaug____>
empty list

[08:30:02.0000] <annevk>
ah yeah, the comment says so

[08:31:00.0000] <smaug____>
annevk: the callback needs to get some parameter so that { handleBatch: function(b) {}} can be used

[08:31:01.0000] <annevk>
can't you pass "Modification[]" as parameter?

[08:31:02.0000] <annevk>
and not have .modifications

[08:31:03.0000] <annevk>
I think that would make more sense

[08:32:00.0000] <smaug____>
I could, but then one would need to track to which batch the modification is related to

[08:32:01.0000] <smaug____>
I mean if the same callback is used with many ModificationBatches

[08:33:00.0000] <smaug____>
and the callback itself call some of the methods of the ModificationBatch

[08:33:01.0000] <annevk>
is there a use for that?

[08:33:02.0000] <smaug____>
in the callback you may want to call unbatch*()

[08:38:00.0000] <annevk>
what are the ways to make .modifications longer than 1?

[08:38:01.0000] <annevk>
is that stuff like innerHTML, doing things from the callback, inserting DocumentFragment?

[08:41:00.0000] <smaug____>
yeah

[08:43:00.0000] <smaug____>
and probably dom range modifications could utilize that too

[08:43:01.0000] <annevk>
but for setAttribute insertBefore etc. not invoked from the callback it would typically be 1?

[08:43:02.0000] <smaug____>
typically 1

[08:44:00.0000] <annevk>
specifying this would require some very careful algorithms to make it nice

[08:44:01.0000] <annevk>
but seems doable

[08:45:00.0000] <smaug____>
it shouldn't be too hard

[08:46:00.0000] <smaug____>
since, now that I think of it, the batching works quite similarly to gecko's DOMSubtreeModified batching

[08:47:00.0000] <smaug____>
you start a batch and end it, and the outer-most "end" (if there are nested start-ends) fires the callback

[08:47:01.0000] <smaug____>
but anyway, it possible that Google objects the approach

[08:48:00.0000] <smaug____>
and if that is the case, I'm not sure how to proceed with mutation events replacements

[08:50:00.0000] <smaug____>
perhaps someone from Opera could write a new proposal and everyone would be happy with it ;)

[08:54:00.0000] <smaug____>
but let's see what kinds of comments the proposal gets

[08:59:00.0000] <annevk>

[09:00:00.0000] <annevk>
smaug____, I guess I could write a proposal that splits your Modification interface :p

[09:06:00.0000] <annevk>
smaug____, I guess innerHTML is actually also one modification

[09:06:01.0000] <annevk>
of the childList

[09:14:00.0000] <smaug____>

[10:12:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Oh jeez, he was "inspired by Lisp's cdddr".  Those are some of the worst functions in the language.

[10:12:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Replaced in a ridiculously more readably fashion by NTH and NTH-CDR.

[10:13:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me tries to work out what that's an abbreviation for

[10:13:01.0000] <Philip`>
cod udder?

[10:13:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
"contents of decrement register"

[10:13:03.0000] <Philip`>
Oh, of course

[10:13:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
Originally the address and decrement registers were used to store Lisp conses (2-tuples), thus the names CAR and CDR.

[10:14:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
cdddr is just repeated cdr, equivalent in this case to "throw away the first three elements and gimme what's left"

[10:15:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
And you can mix a and d there.  Most impls support up to three.

[10:15:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Though I always forget which order they're applied in, which is why I dont' use them.

[10:15:02.0000] <Philip`>
Stick to palindromes so the order doesn't matter

[10:16:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Sensible idea.

[10:16:01.0000] <Philip`>
though you may have to reorganise your data structures in order to access them in that manner

[10:16:02.0000] <Philip`>
but that's a minor price to pay

[10:16:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
While you're at it, you can haiku-optimize the code too.

[10:22:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me wonders if any languages other than Perl have a poetry chapter in their primary reference book

[10:29:00.0000] <Hixie>
the html spec has poems in it that were specifically written for the spec :-)

[10:29:01.0000] <jgraham>

[10:54:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me wonders how to implement UI for an unbounded slider

[10:54:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, map it bijectively to (0, 1), and have it zoom in as you push the slider toward either edge.

[10:55:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
All we really need is a dense totally ordered set without endpoints here, it doesn't have to be R.

[10:55:01.0000] <zewt>
of course, experience with "importance" flags on email tells us that some people will set all of their changes, no matter how trivial, to the highest value available

[10:55:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Of course, any two dense totally ordered sets without endpoints are isomorphic if they're of the same cardinality.

[10:55:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
zewt, that's why there is no highest value!

[10:56:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
It will depend on how long people are willing to type digits, or let the slider scroll.

[10:56:01.0000] <zewt>
unless you're willing to send 500-megabyte numbers over the wire, there's always a highest value

[10:56:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, yeah, eventually you're going to hit the server's configured POST size limit.

[10:57:00.0000] <zewt>
and more to the point (as far as this has a point), the fact that some people will always use a really high value regardless of importance would break the system for everyone else

[10:58:00.0000] <zewt>
i suppose that suggests needing a weighting value: if people rate the stuff you're doing as "unimportant" and you're marking it "important", your importance values are reduced

[12:08:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[12:09:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
oal, iframes are allowed to navigate the parent page, so in principle there's not much you can do.  Sites are allowed to stop themselves from being framed if they don't want to be.

[12:10:00.0000] <annevk>
serialization is somewhat done

[12:10:01.0000] <annevk>
but is going to be moved from CSSOM to individual CSS modules

[12:11:00.0000] <oal>
AryehGregor: Oh, ok. Thanks :(

[12:11:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[12:44:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[12:45:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[12:45:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:04:01.0000] <jgraham>

[13:05:00.0000] <jgraham>

₂

[13:09:01.0000] <jgraham>

[13:12:00.0000] <jgraham>

[13:12:01.0000] <jgraham>

[15:37:01.0000] <jarek>
is there any performance difference between element.setAttribute('blah1', 'blah2') and element.dataset.blah1 = 'blah2'?

[15:39:00.0000] <jarek>
I'm currently using custom attributes all over the place and I'm wondering whether switching to HTML5 datasets would make sense

[15:39:01.0000] <Philip`>

[15:39:02.0000] <Philip`>
since dataset is just an API to get/set content attributes

[15:40:00.0000] <Philip`>
so it's doing the same amount of DOM manipulation either way

[15:43:00.0000] <jarek>

[15:46:00.0000] <Hixie>

[15:46:01.0000] <The_8472>
jarek, you shouldn't set custom attributes directly on dom nodes anyway. it's bad practice for various reasons.

[15:46:02.0000] <Hixie>

[15:46:03.0000] <Hixie>
if you're not, the performance aspects of this are probably irrelevant anyway

[16:16:00.0000] <The_8472>
/me points at corporations having 1st amendment rights in the US.

[16:17:00.0000] <Hixie>
page 11 has a sentence that just says "Who knows?"

[16:17:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Why shouldn't they have them?  They're basically just collections of people.  Your right to free speech shouldn't be affected by who you're being paid by.

[16:18:00.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: if we could imprison the collection of people, that might have more weight

[16:18:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
You can imprison individual people who individually did things wrong.  Corporations don't have volition, they only have assets.  They're controlled entirely by individual people.

[16:18:02.0000] <The_8472>
http://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/22/us/politics/22scotus.html

[16:18:03.0000] <The_8472>
therefore corporations shouldn't have the same rights as people.

[16:19:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
They don't.  The people they employ do.

[16:19:01.0000] <The_8472>
see... that's how it should be, not how it is.

[16:19:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or rather, the rights that have are corollaries of the rights of their employees.

[16:20:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
People who run ads or lobby Congress on behalf of a corporation aren't any less entitled to do so than people who do so on behalf of individuals or themselves.

[16:20:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Just because you were told to do it by a manager in exchange for a paycheck from a corporate bank account doesn't mean you have any less right to do it.

[16:21:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me always gets bored of reading court decisions by the time he gets to the dissents

[16:21:01.0000] <Hixie>
i don't mind them having rights if they have responsibilities to go with them

[16:21:02.0000] <The_8472>
just because you work for a company does not mean they are entitled to represent your political opinion

[16:22:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Of course they aren't.  But they can pay you to exercise your right of political speech on their behalf.  That's all corporations can ever do -- they can't talk or write anything *themselves*.  They're legal fictions.  Any speech is necessarily speech by some person.

[16:22:01.0000] <wilhelm>
The_8472: They usually don't. They represent the political opinion of the owners, if any.

[16:23:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hixie, constitutional rights in America are generally viewed as unalienable, not as being granted in exchange for fulfilling responsibilities.

[16:23:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Convicted murderers spending a life sentence in prison still have the same right to free speech as anyone.

[16:24:00.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: i'm not saying they're directly linked, just that i would be happy with one if the other existed.

[16:25:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hixie, well, corporations basically only have assets.  When it comes to the disposition of those assets, they have similar responsibilities to individuals, often much greater responsibilities (depending on the type of corporation).  That is, they can be held fiscally liable for breaking the law.  But if it's anything non-monetary, you can't really take actions against a corporation, you have to take action against the individuals responsible.

[16:25:01.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: e.g. if someone were to kill all the fish in a sea due to reckless negligence while doing something in that sea, they could be expected to suffer consequences, not be immediately invited to continue doing that thing in the same sea and others, as well as spending large sums of money influencing political decisions that control those consequences

[16:26:00.0000] <The_8472>
/me points at the wallstreet. diffusion of responsibility to the max. they rake in millions and billions by gambling with other people's money (and losing) and get away with a slap on the wrist (to individuals) and practically no regulation at all (towards the companies)

[16:26:01.0000] <The_8472>
they cause far more damage than your lowly criminals that may get many-year sentences...

[16:26:02.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: i'd be fine with it if the individuals were held responsible too

[16:27:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hixie, that's orthogonal to the question of corporations.  "Corporation" doesn't mean "big business", it means an entity that can legally act as a person in some respects.  Small charities and whatever are also often incorporated.

[16:27:01.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: unfortunately, in the US (and many other places), corporations act as responsibility shields

[16:27:02.0000] <wilhelm>
Indeed. “because the corporation is legally considered the "person," individual shareholders are not legally responsible for the corporation's debts and damages beyond their investment in the corporation”

[16:27:03.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: for both the matter of responsibility and the matter of free speech, the problem is proportionally bigger as the company gets bigger.

[16:28:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's not the corporation that's shielding anything, it's the money and influence.  Corporations are designed to be a good vehicle for concentrating arbitrarily large amounts of money, so it just so happens that any organization of note is going to be incorporated.

[16:28:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
That's not the fault of the incorporation.

[16:28:02.0000] <The_8472>
Hixie, it's not just corporations. political parties or bureaucratic machineries are exactly the same. it's all about diffusing responsibility so much that in the end nobody is responsible at all. or that just some symbolic heads will roll even after biggest fuckups that you can imagine

[16:28:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
If incorporation didn't exist, you'd see the same thing with large private businesses.

[16:29:00.0000] <Hixie>
The_8472: yeah, responsibility diffusion really is the problem. the rights get concentrated, but the responsibilities diffused.

[16:29:01.0000] <wilhelm>
The shielding of individual shareholders is a wonderful tool to encourage the establishment of new businesses, and awfully scary when said businesses grow bigger and more powerful than small nation-states.

[16:29:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's simpler than that, it's just that large businesses are powerful enough to have bargaining power with the government.

[16:30:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
In many cases they can credibly threaten the government.

[16:30:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
For instance, a big business could threaten to leave a particular state if it's taxed too heavily.

[16:30:02.0000] <wilhelm>
Or threaten its employees, customers or the general populace.

[16:30:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
That could cause thousands of people to lose their jobs, which would create a big backlash by the general public against the politicians in power.

[16:31:00.0000] <The_8472>
shareholders are another issue when they get dividents. they're syphoning off money from other people's work, even when the company has reached the point of being self-sustaining. so instead of accumulating money within the company to reinvest it gets drained, thus potentially slowing innovation just to fill a few private people's pockets.

[16:31:01.0000] <The_8472>
i know that shares are an important tool to get investments... but in some cases it's just counterproductive

[16:31:02.0000] <The_8472>
the value of the shares themselves should be sufficient

[16:31:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
The_8472, well, yes, that's how capitalism works.  In a capitalist society, it's very easy to start businesses, because investors have the promise of exorbitant returns.

[16:32:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Most large companies don't pay dividends, though.

[16:32:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
And if they do, it's only a very small fraction of profit, like one or two percent.

[16:32:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
So it's not a big deal in the scheme of things.

[16:32:03.0000] <wilhelm>
The growth of the value of the company is usually sufficient.

[16:32:04.0000] <The_8472>
unless someone buys them up, changes the rules and syphons off money, seen that all too often

[16:33:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Right, and dividends slow down the company's growth sometimes.

[16:33:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
The_8472, hostile takeovers of that sort are very rare.  A publicly-traded company almost always has far higher market capitalization than assets.  Usually when you have that sort of systematic buy-out, it's an attempt to merge one company into a larger one or such.

[16:34:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
But it's hard to pull off, because trying it causes the stock price to shoot up.

[16:34:01.0000] <The_8472>
<AryehGregor> It's simpler than that, it's just that large businesses are powerful enough to have bargaining power with the government. <- that's one aspect, but not the only one. just look at all the externalties that companies cause and that the taxpayer has to wipe up after them

[16:34:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Anyway, if you do buy a lot of stock in the company, it's rarely in your interest to try grabbing the assets and running.  You want to hold onto the stock and let it go up in price, then sell it.  That almost always provides better returns.

[16:35:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Except if the company's stock price has really crashed, then it's sometimes worthwhile to buy it just for the sake of liquidating it.

[16:35:01.0000] <The_8472>
oh, you don't grab the assets. you slowly bleed money from them, then sell it again while it's still somewhat performing

[16:35:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
The_8472, practically any economic activity causes externalities, both positive and negative.  Big businesses can bring a lot of positive economic effects, like greatly reduced costs through economy of scale.

[16:36:00.0000] <The_8472>
i'm talking about negative externalties, obviously.

[16:36:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
They can devote a much larger amount of their budget to R&D and innovation, etc.

[16:36:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, yes, but you can't fairly complain about the negative externalities unless you have evidence that they outweigh the positive externalities.

[16:36:03.0000] <The_8472>
which sometimes exceed even the profit that the companies themselves make (look at nuclear fuel processing and waste storage cycles)

[16:37:00.0000] <The_8472>
it's basically cheap power for the economy in exchange for the govt funding the whole infrastructure and waste management for millions of years to come.

[16:39:00.0000] <wilhelm>
AryehGregor: Sure you can. I spend all day searching for an complaining about the few negative issues in otherweise good software. I don't see why the management of this planet's productive resources should be exempt from any criticism. Quite the contrary.

[16:43:00.0000] <The_8472>
you could go even further... we're putting some of those negative externalties on those who don't see anything of the positive ones (i.e. everything that isn't human)

[08:24:00.0000] <timeless>
--note, the following messages were composed while offline (see comments about using bugzilla while offline...) --

[08:24:01.0000] <timeless>
AryehGregor: mikesmith could read the irc logs :)

[08:24:02.0000] <timeless>
AryehGregor: there have been proposals for dealing w/ mass changes

[08:24:03.0000] <timeless>
sadly, as someone who does mass changes and deals w/ them, it's actually valuable to see each individual message

[08:24:04.0000] <timeless>
since i often screw up say 3% of the bugs i touch in mass changes

[08:24:05.0000] <timeless>
and there's no way you'll spot that while doing the mass change nor in a single email report

[08:24:06.0000] <timeless>
jgraham: in theory one could try to do it directly, but bugzilla keeps track of whom has seen which comment/change

[08:24:07.0000] <timeless>
which means it requires touching each user reference for each bug

[08:24:08.0000] <timeless>
otherwise the next touch to the bug will trigger the unsent changes

[08:25:00.0000] <timeless>
AryehGregor: depending on what you want to do w/ mass changes, you can open the query in a decent version of gmail and use <n> to quickly scan through them

[08:25:01.0000] <timeless>
or you can use select all (in that decent version of gmail) and mark as read

[08:25:02.0000] <timeless>
(there are lame versions of gmail -- in case you're wondering-- where you can't do these things, e.g. the java, html [/h], and mobile [/x])

[08:25:03.0000] <timeless>
zewt: importance also goes the other way, someone will set a very important thing to trivial so that it won't flag a manager :)

[08:25:04.0000] <timeless>
Philip`: i make mass changes to thousands of bugs. having to click thousands links in a bugmail to get back my thousands of bugmails would not be fun

[08:25:05.0000] <timeless>
AryehGregor: there are a couple of reasons to want functional archives of bugzilla:

[08:25:06.0000] <timeless>
1. bugzilla search sucks -- gmail search (free text) is much better

[08:25:07.0000] <timeless>
2. when you make a mistake, it's much easier to undo it if you have the bugmail

[08:25:08.0000] <timeless>
3. bugzilla data reflects current info (e.g. see when AryehGregor renamed his bugzilla account), bugmail reflects data as it was

[08:25:09.0000] <timeless>
4. some people work offline (even gmail supports this)

[08:25:10.0000] <timeless>
AryehGregor: re calendar to find day of week, that's awesome

[08:25:11.0000] <timeless>
/me just hovers over the w7 system notification area and it tells me the day of week

[08:25:12.0000] <timeless>
/me is no longer offline

[08:32:01.0000] <timeless>

[08:32:02.0000] <timeless>

[08:32:03.0000] <timeless>
the problem is that bugzilla really can't create those emails later

[08:33:00.0000] <timeless>
e.g. if the mass changer is AryehGregor, and i get the email and then he changes his email address

[08:33:01.0000] <timeless>
and then i click the link asking for his mass changes to be split

[08:33:02.0000] <timeless>
the emails bugzilla would give me would have the *wrong* changer address in them

[08:33:03.0000] <timeless>
and if he changes his real name to claim he's on vacation

[08:33:04.0000] <timeless>
then i'd see that he sent them while on vacation

[08:33:05.0000] <timeless>
...

[08:33:06.0000] <timeless>
the result is bugzilla would have to queue the possible email for all possible recipients

[08:33:07.0000] <timeless>
which would be really bad for storage for bugzilla

[08:34:00.0000] <Philip`>
Disk space is cheap, so queueing is easy

[08:34:01.0000] <Philip`>
They'd compress well too :-)

[08:34:02.0000] <timeless>
well, they would compress well yes

[08:34:03.0000] <zewt>
why? save the body of the outbound message, one per change

[08:34:04.0000] <timeless>
but bugzillas tend to use mysql

[08:34:05.0000] <timeless>
which probably sucks at compressing

[08:35:00.0000] <timeless>
they'd only compress well as a complete set, not as individual messages

[08:35:01.0000] <Philip`>
Concatenate all the messages, gzip them, then store them in a BLOB column, and hope no database administrator notices your terrible abuse of SQL

[08:35:02.0000] <timeless>
i suppose you could compose an MBox for each user

[08:35:03.0000] <zewt>
would also allow you to do things like request a full email audit trail of a bug later on

[08:35:04.0000] <gsnedders>
timeless: MySQL can compress parts

[08:36:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Philip`: mindblowing. Is there Krid, too?

[08:36:01.0000] <timeless>
gsnedders: databases are generally designed for pigeon holes, and compressing an individual hole doesn't gain much

[08:36:02.0000] <Philip`>
Alternatively, maybe emails could have some extra header which contains some globally unique mail-set identifier, and mail clients could have a "select all in same set as this message" feature

[08:36:03.0000] <zewt>
well, it would if you were storing a block of text repeated thousands of times, but again I don't see why you need to store them all

[08:36:04.0000] <timeless>
but i suppose if you arranged a portion for inidividual recipients... it might be doable

[08:37:00.0000] <timeless>
Philip`: so...

[08:37:01.0000] <Philip`>
then bulk change mails would get put into the same set

[08:37:02.0000] <timeless>
on that count, there is a mass change header in the mails

[08:37:03.0000] <timeless>

[10:58:00.0000] <mhausenblas>
can you help me re a CORS question pls?

[10:58:01.0000] <mhausenblas>
now, a month ago someone pointed out that I have a syntax mistake in http://enable-cors.org/#how-apache

[10:59:00.0000] <mhausenblas>
people pointed out that Access-Control-Allow-Origin: "*" is wrong and it should be Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *

[11:00:00.0000] <mhausenblas>
now, I get a request from someone saying 'I spent a while trying to debug this with our apache servers.' and actually it is the other way round

[11:00:01.0000] <mhausenblas>
so, my inital version was right (?)

[11:00:02.0000] <mhausenblas>
any idea, annevk?

[11:01:00.0000] <mhausenblas>
hmmm ... I guess you're not around annevk  - I leave you a message on G+ then ...

[11:01:01.0000] <Philip`>
http://dvcs.w3.org/hg/cors/raw-file/tip/Overview.html#access-control-allow-origin-response-header looks like it says there shouldn't be any quotes

[11:02:00.0000] <gsnedders>
mhausenblas: there shouldn't be any quotes

[11:02:01.0000] <mhausenblas>
hmmm

[11:02:02.0000] <Philip`>
and later it says "If the Access-Control-Allow-Origin header value is the literal "*" character and the credentials flag is false return pass and terminate this algorithm."

[11:02:03.0000] <mhausenblas>
right

[11:02:04.0000] <Philip`>
which sounds like it's a single character

[11:03:00.0000] <mhausenblas>
so, the first request was right

[11:04:00.0000] <mhausenblas>
I just wonder why the new request (from a guy who claims that he's debugged it with Apache) thinks it's not the case

[11:04:01.0000] <mhausenblas>
I must confess that the spec is rather clear, the BNF says it all

[11:04:02.0000] <mhausenblas>
an Apache bug, maybe?

[11:04:03.0000] <mhausenblas>
nah

[11:05:00.0000] <Philip`>
Maybe 'Header set Access-Control-Allow-Origin *' should be 'Header set Access-Control-Allow-Origin "*"'

[11:05:01.0000] <gsnedders>
mhausenblas: What' she saying it's not the case?

[11:05:02.0000] <gsnedders>
s/What's/Why's/

[11:05:03.0000] <Philip`>
since http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.0/mod/mod_headers.html indicates it sometimes wants the value to be double-quoted

[11:05:04.0000] <Philip`>
(and it'll strip the quotes off before sending the header, presumably)

[11:05:05.0000] <mhausenblas>
hmmm

[11:06:00.0000] <mhausenblas>
the person who says that the current status at http://enable-cors.org/#how-apache is wrong literally says:

[11:06:01.0000] <mhausenblas>
In the 'For Apache' section, please change :

[11:06:02.0000] <mhausenblas>
Header set Access-Control-Allow-Origin *

[11:06:03.0000] <mhausenblas>
to :

[11:06:04.0000] <mhausenblas>
Header set Access-Control-Allow-Origin "*"

[11:06:05.0000] <mhausenblas>
I spent a while trying to debug this with our apache servers.

[11:06:06.0000] <Philip`>
The Apache documentation sounds pretty vague about syntax

[11:06:07.0000] <mhausenblas>
now I'm a bit in trouble, ain't I?

[11:06:08.0000] <Philip`>
like what strings have to be double-quoted

[11:06:09.0000] <Philip`>
and how you could include a double quote inside a string if you wanted to

[11:07:00.0000] <mhausenblas>

[12:50:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Ms2ger: The double-consonant rules are inconsistent in English.

[12:50:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Otherwise we'd say "editting".  I sometimes autocorrect away from doubles, precisely because of the word "editting".

[12:51:00.0000] <Ms2ger>
Everything is inconssistent in English

[12:52:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, a reasonably reliable rule is that you double the last consonant if the word is accented on the last syllable, and don't double it otherwise.

[12:52:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
For when you're adding verb suffixes like -ed or -ing.

[12:52:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Hmm, never thought of that rule.

[12:52:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Not entirely reliable, but works okay.

[12:53:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I think I know it because in a MUD in like 1999, I reported a typo in one of the room descriptions where it said "worshiped", which I thought should be "worshipped", and one of the GMs educated me.

[12:53:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
(I then promptly pointed out another room description where it said "worshipped" instead of "worshiped", which he corrected.)

[12:54:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[12:54:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

[13:57:01.0000] <timeless>

[13:57:02.0000] <timeless>

[13:58:00.0000] <timeless>

[14:25:02.0000] <timeless>

[14:25:03.0000] <zewt>
right, I'm saying the signature shouldn't include that, since it's (probably) normal for mailing lists to change it

[14:25:04.0000] <timeless>
a dkim aware mailinglist will need to avoid munging any dkim signed fields

[14:26:00.0000] <timeless>
from google's perspective, the mailinglist is at fault

[14:26:01.0000] <timeless>
from my perspective, i'd like to know what a mailing list can do instead

[14:26:02.0000] <timeless>
sadly finding *that* info is painful

[14:26:03.0000] <timeless>
one approach is to take my message and stick it as a MIME attachment

[14:26:04.0000] <timeless>
(as the only part)

[14:26:05.0000] <zewt>
if mailing lists typically change Sender, then google's signatures are clearly at fault (i don't know, off-hand, whether changing that header is actually typical or if whatwg is doing something unusual)

[14:26:06.0000] <timeless>
and stick a <mailinglist> envelope around it

[14:28:00.0000] <zewt>
if every mailman installation does that, then google is clearly at fault in practice

[14:28:01.0000] <timeless>
i think mailman basically needs to change

[14:28:02.0000] <zewt>
(i'm assuming whatwg is just a standard-issue mailman install like the other billion of them)

[14:28:03.0000] <timeless>
it needs to strip out the DKIM signature if it's valid

[14:28:04.0000] <timeless>
and replace it with its own DKIM signature

[14:28:05.0000] <timeless>
which is correct

[14:28:06.0000] <timeless>
it's claiming sender=whatwg

[14:29:00.0000] <timeless>
so it should just resign it with sender=whatwg

[14:29:01.0000] <timeless>
http://wiki.list.org/display/DEV/DKIM

[14:30:00.0000] <zewt>
timeless: but practically speaking, if every mailman list in the world has this problem, then google is in error showing a warning like this before the problem is solved (or at least in the process of being solved, eg. a mailman update available)

[14:30:01.0000] <timeless>
well

[14:30:02.0000] <zewt>
(i'm assuming there isn't, since it looks like whatwg is already on the latest version)

[14:30:03.0000] <timeless>
could i interest you in working on it w/ me?

[14:30:04.0000] <timeless>
i'm seriously contemplating trying to fix mailman

[14:31:00.0000] <timeless>
i'm fairly certain that no one has fixed it

[14:31:01.0000] <timeless>
by `fixing`, i mean `writing a patch which implements one strategy`

[14:31:02.0000] <timeless>
my proposed strategy is this:

[14:31:03.0000] <timeless>
take the existing signature, if it's valid, store it with a new prefix, munge the message, and resign it for the mailer

[14:32:00.0000] <timeless>
if the signature isn't valid, add a note that it wasn't valid and <dunno, possibly just drop the message on the floor, or optionally send it to moderation, or munge the message and add a broken signature and send it off>

[14:33:00.0000] <timeless>
i'd do the code under the mailman license (whatever that is), and offer it to mailman and any lists i use

[14:34:00.0000] <timeless>
(yes, this has bothered me for a while, but the goal of google here is to get people to implement a fix)

[14:34:01.0000] <timeless>
i think ideally google would have a way to let individuals whitelist individual mailing lists in the interim

[14:34:02.0000] <timeless>
until people like you/me fix the mailing list software to stop breaking signatures

[14:34:03.0000] <zewt>
i'm not familiar with the nuts and bolts of how DKIM works

[14:34:04.0000] <timeless>
zewt: don't worry about it, we'd figure it out

[14:35:00.0000] <timeless>
the documentation seems pretty clear

[14:35:01.0000] <timeless>

[14:36:00.0000] <timeless>

[14:36:01.0000] <zewt>

[14:37:00.0000] <zewt>

[14:37:01.0000] <timeless>

[14:37:02.0000] <zewt>

[14:37:03.0000] <timeless>

[14:39:00.0000] <timeless>

[14:41:00.0000] <timeless>

n't

[15:43:00.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: yt?

[15:43:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
rniwa, yep.

[15:43:02.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: what do you think of edit-action event?

[15:43:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
rniwa, not sure.  Does such a thing exist yet, or is this just a proposal?  What are the use-cases?

[15:43:04.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: no

[15:44:00.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: so, some editors implement their own editing commands

[15:44:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Right.

[15:44:02.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: or replace the UA's by their own

[15:44:03.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: but there's currently no way of doing this

[15:44:04.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: other than manually intercepting keydown

[15:44:05.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: and other events

[15:45:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
So just an event that fires whenever execCommand() is run?

[15:45:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or, no.

[15:45:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Are you talking about things like "user types text" or "user inserts a line break"?

[15:45:03.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: yes

[15:45:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Ah, okay.

[15:45:05.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: we should fire an event for both

[15:45:06.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: that's why I said user action

[15:45:07.0000] <AryehGregor>
Right, I see.

[15:45:08.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: could be beforeEditingCommand

[15:45:09.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: or beforeEditingAction

[15:45:10.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: I mean the name could be anything

[15:46:00.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: but the point is that we'll give some standard name for user editing actions

[15:46:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
And the default action would be to run insertText or insertParagraph or whatever.

[15:46:02.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: e.g. inserting new line should be InsertLineBreak / InsertParagraph, etc...

[15:46:03.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: right

[15:46:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Why is this better than intercepting keydown etc.?

[15:46:05.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: I mean I'm certain UA already does this one way or another

[15:46:06.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: intercepting keydown is problematic because it depends on each platform

[15:47:00.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: e.g. ctrl+y doesn't necessary mean undo

[15:47:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hmm, I see.

[15:47:02.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: it's cmd+y

[15:47:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Oh, right.

[15:47:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or Ctrl-Shift-Z.

[15:47:05.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: yeah

[15:47:06.0000] <rniwa>
e.g.

[15:47:07.0000] <rniwa>
etc...

[15:47:08.0000] <AryehGregor>
Okay, that makes sense.

[15:47:09.0000] <AryehGregor>
Also for insertLineBreak.

[15:47:10.0000] <rniwa>
also, the user agent may provide some UI such as context menu that triggers editing commands

[15:48:00.0000] <rniwa>
e.g. Safari provides Format in its context enu

[15:48:01.0000] <rniwa>
menu*

[15:48:02.0000] <rniwa>
and lets user bold, italicize, etc.. .text

[15:48:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Interesting.

[15:48:04.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: I guess we can talk more when we meet later this month :)

[15:49:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
So it would make sense to just fire an event for every execCommand() invocation, whether internal to the browser or not.

[15:49:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Sure.  :)

[15:49:02.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: right

[15:50:00.0000] <rniwa>

[15:50:01.0000] <rniwa>
AryehGregor: they might do something slightly different when actions are user triggerd

[15:50:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[15:50:03.0000] <rniwa>
yeah

[15:51:00.0000] <rniwa>

[15:51:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[15:51:02.0000] <rniwa>

[15:51:03.0000] <rniwa>

[15:52:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[19:28:00.0000] <Hixie>

[19:28:01.0000] <Hixie>
same reason

[19:28:02.0000] <Hixie>
(ease of code maintenance/readability, semantics/accessibility, ease of interpretation by search engines or other tools, etc)

[19:29:00.0000] <zewt>

[19:29:01.0000] <zewt>
(not window-modal)

[19:36:00.0000] <jamesr>

[19:36:01.0000] <jamesr>

[19:39:00.0000] <Hixie>
so does <dialog>

[19:39:01.0000] <Hixie>
it means "this is going to be used for a dialog"

[19:41:00.0000] <Hixie>
(more importantly, maybe, it's display:none by default, so in non-CSS UAs you don't have to worry about the dialog showing when not active)

[19:43:00.0000] <zewt>

[08:30:00.0000] <jarek>
"linkElement.href" always returns absolute path while "linkElement.getAttribute('href')" may return either absolute or relative path

[08:30:01.0000] <jarek>
is this behavior the same on all browsers?

[08:33:00.0000] <jarek>
hmm... looks like it's by design as I can reproduce it on every browser

[08:41:00.0000] <smaug____>
jarek: getAttribute() returns the content attribute value

[08:41:01.0000] <smaug____>
so whatever value the attribute has

[08:42:00.0000] <smaug____>
.href returns what is specified in http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/semantics.html#attr-link-href

[08:43:00.0000] <smaug____>
oh, hmm

[08:43:01.0000] <smaug____>
is there a bug in the spec

[08:44:00.0000] <smaug____>
no

[08:44:01.0000] <smaug____>
"If a reflecting IDL attribute is a DOMString attribute whose content attribute is defined to contain a URL, then on getting, the IDL attribute must resolve the value of the content attribute relative to the element and return the resulting absolute URL"

[18:32:00.0000] <benjoffe>
I wonder, would it be good to have a media query

[18:33:00.0000] <benjoffe>
'contrast', that is, say a float (0 -- normal) -> (1 - high contrast) that represents the contrast levels the audience is capable of viewing

[00:56:00.0000] <benjoffe>
I guess there's not much discussion going on here...

[01:08:00.0000] <zcorpan>
"It is basically a formal description of the state-of-the art in the Web platform from 3 years ago." - http://blog.n01se.net/?p=375

[01:13:00.0000] <espadrine>
zcorpan: The most important part of HTML5 is JavaScript? Odd.

[02:05:00.0000] <jgraham>
benjoffe_: Well Sunday evening is not the busiest time

[02:06:00.0000] <benjoffe_>
jgraham: Yeah makes sense (I'm GMT+1000 and often forget the reset of the world is far behind)

[02:07:00.0000] <jgraham>
I expect the people who produce the lowest contrast designs would also be the least likely to use that media query

[02:07:01.0000] <jgraham>
Also, I can't really imagine browsers shipping with UI to set the user preference

[02:08:00.0000] <benjoffe_>
jgraham: The idea though is that I would like to provide say red on black links, but it's not good for those with poor eyesight, it would be good if I could selectively make that a different colour only for those who need it

[02:08:01.0000] <jgraham>
Yes, I understand the idea

[02:09:00.0000] <jgraham>
In general I would expect solutions that work independently of the author (e.g. the readability features in various bookmarks and safari) to be bigger wins

[02:10:00.0000] <benjoffe_>
jgraham: sure features like that are great, but their existence is not enough for me to be able to implement these designs that I'd like to

[02:12:00.0000] <benjoffe_>
I can see it would be difficult to introduce this kind of media query though, as authors won't implement it until browsers support it and browsers won't support it (or at least emphasise it) until many sites use it

[02:14:00.0000] <jgraham>
And users won't set the preference unless it affects sites they use

[02:14:01.0000] <jgraham>
and will be annoyed if they set the pref and still get low-contrast text they can't read

[02:15:00.0000] <benjoffe_>
It could be a ui button that appears only if the site is making use of the query perhaps (kind of like how safari only shows 'reader' if it passes some heuristic)
