[07:53:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
MikeSmith_, for checking disk space I usually use du -m / | sort -nr | head -n 50.

[07:53:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Prints out the top 50 directories by disk space usage.

[07:54:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Although it takes a long time if you have a lot of directories.

[07:56:00.0000] <MikeSmith_>
AryehGregor: cool, thanks

[07:57:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Although one disadvantage is it doesn't print out anything at all until it's done.

[07:57:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Since sort has to wait for all the input before it can output the first line.

[07:58:00.0000] <MikeSmith_>
only takes 13 seconds on my local machine

[07:59:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
du -mx is probably better than du -m, actually, so it doesn't cross filesystem boundaries.

[07:59:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
(since you only care about one filesystem if you want to know what's using space)

[07:59:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me looks hopefully toward a btrfs future where ridiculous issues like that will go away, along with war and world hunger

[07:59:03.0000] <MikeSmith_>
taking a bit longer on my server...

[08:00:00.0000] <MikeSmith_>
/me googles btrfs

[08:00:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I've seen it take hours on occasion.  But it's just du that's taking that long, it would take that long regardless.

[08:00:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Because it has to look at every directory in the filesystem.

[08:03:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
btrfs is the cool next-gen filesystem for Linux that's basically a total ripoff of all the good ideas of ZFS, but on an OS that more than three people actually care about.

[08:03:01.0000] <MikeSmith_>
took 3 minutes 45 seconds on my server filesystem of ~16GB

[08:03:02.0000] <MikeSmith_>
heh

[08:03:03.0000] <MikeSmith_>
me dunno much about ZFS either?

[08:03:04.0000] <MikeSmith_>
Sun?

[08:04:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
In particular, it encourages you to put everything on one big filesystem, and divide things up into "subvolumes" that you don't have reserve space for in advance.  So you can divide the space up into subvolumes for different parts of the filesystem and therefore easily track what's using how much space, quickly remove entire subvolumes, etc., but not have to waste space by deciding how much to reserve for each subvolume in advance.

[08:05:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
But you can put limits on how big each subvolume is allowed to get, and track how big each one is, and otherwise mostly handle them as independent filesystems, so you get almost all the benefits of separate filesystems.

[08:05:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
But there are zillions of other cool features, like online resize (shrink as well as grow), online fsck, extremely low-cost snapshotting of subvolumes, improved performance on many workloads, etc. etc. etc.

[08:14:00.0000] <MikeSmith_>
sounds too good to be true

[08:14:01.0000] <MikeSmith_>
there must be a catch

[08:15:00.0000] <espadrine>
AryehGregor: By the way, what is "online resize and fsck"? That is one thing I never understood about Btrfs.

[08:17:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
MikeSmith_, the catch is it's not stable and who knows when it will be stable and until it's stable it will probably lock up and/or eat your data.

[08:18:00.0000] <MikeSmith_>
ah

[08:18:01.0000] <MikeSmith_>
that's definitely a bit of a downside

[08:18:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yeah, that's the sort of thing that tends to put a damper on filesystem innovation.

[08:18:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
If your scheduler or something messes up you can always just switch back to an old kernel and big deal, but filesystems messing up is a bit more of a practical problem.

[08:19:00.0000] <espadrine>
Well, ZFS has been stable for some time...

[08:19:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
espadrine, "online resize" means you can increase or decrease the size of the filesystem online, like if you add or remove a disk.  ext4 (and ext3 and ext2) can increase filesystem size but not decrease.

[08:19:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Online, I mean.

[08:19:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
They can decrease offline, i.e., with the filesystem unmounted.

[08:19:04.0000] <espadrine>
oh! good!

[08:20:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Online fsck is what it sounds like, btrfs is supposed to be able to check for and repair errors online instead of requiring you to mount your root filesystem read-only and therefore take the the whole system offline if you want to check for or fix errors.

[08:20:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
ZFS has been stable for some time but still reportedly has reliability issues.

[08:21:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I know of more than one site that used ZFS but then switched away because they had problems with it failing randomly.

[08:21:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
("more than one site" being toolserver.org, and Wikimedia)

[08:21:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Failing randomly or otherwise not living up to expectations.

[08:21:03.0000] <jgraham>
"Online fsck is what it sounds like" - an excuse for yet more tired /. jokes?

[08:21:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
jgraham, ?

[08:21:05.0000] <espadrine>
That could be the fate of Btrfs when released, unfortunately.

[08:23:00.0000] <jgraham>
AryehGregor: Isn't there a whole genre of jokes based around the small Levenshtein distance between the word "fsck" and the word "fuck"?

[08:23:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Probably.

[08:24:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
espadrine, yeah, but Linux is much more widely used, so with any luck it will get much better testing.

[08:24:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I'm not expecting to use it in production anytime within the next few years, though.

[08:25:00.0000] <Philip`>
If quality depends on testing which depends on number of users, that seems to indicate the quality-improvement process is (at least in part) to wait for users to encounter bugs and lose data and then fix those bugs

[08:25:01.0000] <Philip`>
Can't they, like, write it correctly in the first place?

[08:26:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me wishes programming was easier

[08:26:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
If programming was easy, most of the people in this chat room would make a lot less money.  :)

[08:27:00.0000] <jgraham>
If programming was easier we would use it to solve harder problems

[08:27:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
That too.

[08:30:00.0000] <Philip`>
It's only a filesystem, and the API is already designed and implemented many times so they don't have to deal with drastically changing requirements - it doesn't seem like a problem that will always grow until it's slightly too hard to implement

[08:32:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
So you'd think.  But in practice, people want filesystems to do all kinds of things, and people think of ever cleverer ways to do them.

[08:32:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
ZFS and btrfs are a totally different filesystem model from other commonly-used filesystems, they do everything copy-on-write.

[08:32:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
So there are a ton of practical issues to work out.

[08:33:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Like "what happens when you get low on disk space?"  Both of them have issues then.

[08:33:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
btrfs uses some fancy B-tree-based data structure that some guy made up in like 2005.

[08:35:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me thinks it might be interesting if someone did a book collecting articles from developers of lots of projects, explaining what they see as the fundamentally hard problems they have to face, to show why things are never as easy as they superficially appear

[08:35:01.0000] <Philip`>
(Most things I've seen before are focusing on solutions, which is generally less interesting than problems)

[08:36:00.0000] <jgraham>
Probably no one wants to write a book suggesting that they're not clever enough to trivially solve all problems

[08:37:00.0000] <Philip`>
The developers working on a project have already clearly indicated they can't trivially solve all problems, because if they could then they wouldn't still be working on that project

[08:37:01.0000] <Philip`>
so the book would be a good way for them to offer excuses for not having finished the project yet

[08:37:02.0000] <zewt>
i sure don't want to touch a filesystem that hasn't been stable for many years

[08:38:00.0000] <zewt>
given that it's probably the single most critical piece of code on the entire system

[08:38:01.0000] <zewt>
i expect i'll be sticking with XFS for a long time to come

[08:41:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I'm okay with using a filesystem once it's been the default in major distros for a version or two and there are no widespread reports of breakage.

[08:41:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Provided I keep backups of anything important.

[08:42:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
If a million Ubuntu users haven't hit anything really nasty in a year, my desktop isn't important enough that I'm going to worry about being the first.

[08:43:00.0000] <zewt>
well, the default in debian/ubuntu still tends to be ext3/ext4, but i don't trust that

[08:43:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
ext3 has been the default filesystem in Linux for like ten years.

[08:43:02.0000] <Philip`>
Just make sure your backup disks aren't using the new filesystem too

[08:44:00.0000] <zewt>
if a filesystem defaults to doing a lengthy full fsck every N boots by default, that tells me the developers have very little confidence in it

[08:44:01.0000] <espadrine>
zewt: I read somewhere that ext developers had decided never to create ext5

[08:44:02.0000] <espadrine>
they are confident Btrfs will be the future

[08:44:03.0000] <Philip`>
Maybe they'll go straight from ext4 to ext6

[08:44:04.0000] <zewt>
it's very strange that distros still use ext*, since xfs is pretty much better in every way

[08:45:00.0000] <zewt>
for very low-memory systems maybe

[08:45:01.0000] <Ms2ger>
Obviously ext5 would involve writing a spec for each line of code

[08:46:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
espadrine, that was decided a few years ago, yes.  There was a major Linux filesystem summit, and the plan everyone agreed on was to make short-term easy improvements to ext3 in the form of ext4, and consign the long-term future of Linux filesystems to btrfs.

[08:48:00.0000] <espadrine>
AryehGregor: this is going to be a difficult transition... something like Python3

[08:48:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
zewt, what advantage does XFS have over ext4?

[08:48:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Defragmentation?

[08:48:03.0000] <espadrine>
zewt: XFS looks good, I wonder why I haven't heard of it before

[08:48:04.0000] <espadrine>
AryehGregor: it cannot be shrunk

[08:48:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
espadrine, not at all.  You can do an extremely fast in-place upgrade of ext4 to btrfs, with rollback.

[08:49:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
And the difference is mostly transparent, btrfs does everything important ext4 does as far as applications are concerned.

[08:49:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
So it's just a matter of people waiting till it's stable and reliable.

[08:49:02.0000] <zewt>
my experience with xfs is that it just works: reliable, very consistently fast, and i havn't had to do an fsck of any kind since it was pre-release

[08:49:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
zewt, my experience with ext4 is the same.

[08:49:04.0000] <espadrine>
AryehGregor: I meant, people won't want to touch it unless other people use it

[08:49:05.0000] <espadrine>
which is the issue in Python3

[08:50:00.0000] <zewt>
ext* fscks by default every N boots (which you can turn off, but if a filesystem does something that hugely expensive by default, I assume it's for a reason)

[08:50:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
espadrine, to use Python 3 you have to port your code, which is nontrivial for large codebases, and impossible if you rely on unported libraries.

[08:50:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Any random person can switch their machine from ext4 to btrfs for the heck of it today if they want.

[08:50:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
And they do.

[08:51:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
zewt, that could speak to a difference in configuration philosophy more than anything.

[08:51:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
The only time I've had nontrivial filesystem corruption on ext4 was when the underlying disk was bad.

[08:51:02.0000] <Philip`>
espadrine: I think the problem with Python 3 is more that it's worse than Python 2 until everybody else in the world has upgraded (so you can be compatible with their applications/libraries), so nobody wants to bother upgrading

[08:51:03.0000] <zewt>
the philosophy i read into it is "we don't trust our code enough"; others may read what they like, of course

[08:51:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
(there were other times that fsck caught something, but it was some trivial thing that it easily fixed)

[08:51:05.0000] <Philip`>
whereas an individual can change their filesystem regardless of what anyone else does

[08:52:00.0000] <zewt>
the problem with python 3 is it doesn't have a sane upgrade path, so it essentially fragments the language

[08:52:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
zewt, or it could be "we know hardware sometimes goes bad or lies regardless of how good our code is, and we aren't overconfident in our code either".

[08:53:00.0000] <zewt>
AryehGregor: has never happened to me, but i sure have had servers offline for long periods of time due to an un-asked-for fsck on reboot

[08:53:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yes, that's just stupid configuration.

[08:53:02.0000] <zewt>
ymmv etc etc

[08:53:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Although ext4 fsck is much, much faster than ext3 fsck.

[08:54:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hmm, XFS can't be shrunk?

[08:54:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Even offline?

[08:54:02.0000] <zewt>
dunno, never tried

[08:54:03.0000] <Philip`>
/me has never encountered the problem of having too much disk space

[08:54:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
I've had to shrink ext* on occasion.  It's really slow and only works offline, but it works.

[08:55:00.0000] <zewt>
really the only particularly interesting feature of newer filesystems is being able to snapshot (without layering another special block layer underneith), to be able to backup databases directly

[08:55:01.0000] <Philip`>
If you don't mind really slow, copy the data to an external disk then repartition and reformat then copy back

[08:55:02.0000] <zewt>
Philip`: well, if you're working with an array, you don't always have that option

[08:55:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, only works if you have enough empty storage.

[08:56:00.0000] <zewt>
(+ interesting feature to me, of course)

[08:56:01.0000] <Philip`>
/me wouldn't really want to resize partitions unless he already had a backup copy anyway

[08:56:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
btrfs has lots of interesting features beyond snapshotting.

[08:56:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
In-FS RAID looks like it will be really cool.

[08:56:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
You'll be able to choose different RAID levels for different files.

[08:57:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
And it doesn't have the same resyncing problems as normal software RAID.

[08:58:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
So RAID5 for backups (= almost all reads/writes are serial, take up lots of space) but RAID10 for database files (= lots of random read/write), say.

[08:58:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Of course, a lot of this stuff is still on the drawing board.

[08:59:00.0000] <zewt>
more interesting would be intelligent RAID for databases across spinnydisks and SSDs

[09:00:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Oh, and you can copy files instantly, like hard-linking except the file is actually logically totally separate.  That's very cool.

[09:00:01.0000] <zewt>
eg. to be able to get safe writes to disk (which many, especially cheaper, SSDs are very bad at), while being able to use the SSD for reads (where it's an order of magnitude improvement for databases in many cases)

[09:01:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
That's probably best handled at a different layer.

[09:01:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Somewhere below the filesystem layer.

[09:01:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
There's work in that department in Linux, IIRC including something funded by Facebook.

[09:02:00.0000] <zewt>
it can be done at the FS layer logically: report writes as synced to disk as soon as they've hit at least one disk, without waiting for it to be confirmed to all

[09:02:01.0000] <zewt>
(whether you actually want that or not is a matter of policy)

[09:03:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
md already can do that, with the --write-behind= option.  Although of course that's inflexible.

[09:03:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
In particular, the SSD has to be the same size as the other device, which mostly defeats the point.

[09:03:02.0000] <zewt>
of course, different disk sizes and other things mean it's far from trivial

[09:04:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
The better use for SSDs is probably to use them as a read cache only, not a write buffer.  Cheaper SSDs are very slow to write to randomly anyway.

[09:04:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Plus, writes can be buffered a lot already in memory or in battery-backed RAID controllers or such.

[09:05:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Whereas you can't buffer reads, so those are the things you really want to get rid of as much as possible (admittedly depending on workload).

[10:54:00.0000] <eighty4>

[10:55:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, you have to say that it's a great circle, because latitude lines aren't great circles (except the equator).  So a degree of latitude will generally be less distance than a degree of longitude, up to 100% less.

[10:55:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
. . . I mean the other way around.

[10:55:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
A degree of longitude at our latitude is about 70% as long as a degree of latitude.

[10:56:00.0000] <Ms2ger>
In Texas, all circles are great circles.

[11:02:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: No, you had it right the first time.

[11:02:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
latitudinal degrees are smaller than longitudinal over most of the world

[11:02:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
No, because moving a degree of latitude is moving north or south, and that's always along a great circle (one that contains the north and south poles).

[11:02:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Nope.

[11:02:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Since when you're changing latitude, you're actually moving along a longitude line, and vice versa.

[11:02:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
Meridians are longitudinal lines.

[11:03:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Oh, wait, I see what you're saying.

[11:03:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yes, and moving along a longitudinal line is a change in latitude.  Your longitude remains constant.

[11:03:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
It always confuses me.

[11:04:01.0000] <Philip`>

[11:05:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[11:05:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Haha!  We all agree!

[11:05:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, I said a flat torus, which is actually a sort of 2-torus, but maybe you meant that too.

[11:05:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
(since a flat torus can only be embedded in Euclidean space of four or more dimensions)

[11:05:06.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yes.

[11:05:07.0000] <AryehGregor>
(a 4-torus, strictly speaking, would be a four-dimensional manifold in its own right, not two-dimensional)

[11:05:08.0000] <TabAtkins>
My geometry terminology is all kinds of inconsistent.

[11:06:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
So yeah, a 2-torus embedded in 4d so it's flat in 3d

[11:06:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[13:04:01.0000] <timeless>
my general feeling on Contact cards is:

[13:04:02.0000] <timeless>
support Name[]

[13:05:00.0000] <timeless>
where each element in Name is a full (or not) name, so someone could have Name = ['Dan Smith', 'Daniel Smith', 'Danny

[13:05:01.0000] <timeless>
Smith']

[13:06:00.0000] <timeless>
anything which performs a search should search across all Name[] elements of all Contacts[]

[13:06:01.0000] <timeless>
If someone wants to have a nickname, they would just include it as another entry in Name[]

[13:06:02.0000] <Ms2ger>
As long as it supports ["Ms2ger"], I'm happy with it

[13:06:03.0000] <timeless>
it woul

[13:06:04.0000] <timeless>
d

[13:07:00.0000] <timeless>
My general approach to the other side (transmission) is to encourage all UAs to allow users to modify cards before transmitting

[13:07:01.0000] <timeless>
especially to enable selection of a subset of fields and values

[13:07:02.0000] <timeless>
as well as to provide substitutions and additions

[13:07:03.0000] <timeless>
so you could Name[]+= "Your roommate from freshman year of college"

[13:35:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
"Chiloni" means you don't believe in or care about religion at all.  "Masorti" means you're sympathetic to religion and observe some practices at least when they suit you, maybe including keeping kosher and praying, but aren't fully observant (e.g., don't observe the Sabbath or conjugal laws or something).  "Dati"/"charedi" means you're religious, you theoretically try to keep all of halacha.  The difference between "dati" and "charedi" is so

[13:35:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
cial: datim are a part of the secular world, charedim aren't.

[13:36:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
E.g., datim generally serve in the military, go to college, and get jobs, while charedim don't.

[13:36:01.0000] <timeless>
right

[13:36:02.0000] <timeless>
/me should be able to memorize that

[13:36:03.0000] <erlehmann>

[13:36:05.0000] <timeless>

[13:36:06.0000] <AryehGregor>

[14:04:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, under court precedent, the state can impose any restriction on free speech provided it can show that a) there's a compelling state interest, b) the restriction is narrowly tailored to serve that interest.

[14:04:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's strict scrutiny, that's all.

[14:04:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
There are certain exceptions where the state isn't even subject to strict scrutiny, based on the traditional application of free speech historically in America, like obscenity.

[14:50:00.0000] <Hixie>

[14:50:01.0000] <Hixie>

[14:51:00.0000] <Hixie>

[14:51:01.0000] <Hixie>
should we put that restriction in the spec?

[14:54:00.0000] <Philip`>

[14:55:00.0000] <Hixie>
oh it's certainly possible to shoot yourself in the foot if we allow https:// to ws:// connections

[15:19:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: what do you mean by "Web Sockets by definition are same-origin with whatever script created them"? I would say that it's cross-origin by definition since it always connects to a different scheme

[15:26:00.0000] <Hixie>
sicking: well i guess it depends what you mean by "origin"

[15:27:00.0000] <Hixie>
sicking: on the web you can only access same-origin resources. The way I look at it, CORS and WebSockets get around this by allowing servers to opt-in to being treated as same-origin in specific cases.

[15:28:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: that's not how i see CORS

[15:28:01.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: i see it as a way for a server to say "you can read this data even though you are from a different origin"

[15:28:02.0000] <Hixie>
what's the origin of an <img> obtained using CORS?

[15:28:03.0000] <Hixie>
of the image data of an <img>, i mean

[15:29:00.0000] <Hixie>
it's not cross-origin; if it was, it would still taint canvas

[15:29:01.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: it's the origin of the server it was loaded from

[15:29:02.0000] <Hixie>
not according to the spec

[15:29:03.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: i think that makes the definition of "origin" much more complex

[15:29:04.0000] <Hixie>
what's the origin of a document on http://example.com/ if it's loaded in an <iframe sandbox>?

[15:30:00.0000] <Hixie>
not http://example.com/, according to the spec

[15:30:01.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: that i'm not quite sure of. I agree it's not "http://example.com/"

[15:30:02.0000] <Hixie>
what's the origin of an about:blank document? rarely if ever is it "about:blank"

[15:30:03.0000] <sicking>
agreed

[15:30:04.0000] <Hixie>
anyway my point is the "origin" is a tuple that doesn't necessarily match the url of the resource

[15:31:00.0000] <Hixie>
with websockets there isn't really a concept of origin since there's no origin check after tha handshake

[15:31:01.0000] <Hixie>
the

[15:31:02.0000] <sicking>
the origin check is part of the handshake

[15:31:03.0000] <sicking>
similar to CORS

[15:31:04.0000] <Hixie>
the only origin involved in that check is the script's origin

[15:31:05.0000] <Hixie>
the server just has to echo it

[15:31:06.0000] <sicking>
if you consider CORS being part of the handshake for crosssite xhr

[22:46:00.0000] <Hixie>

[22:46:01.0000] <Hixie>

[13:32:00.0000] <espadrine>
The spec states that in a <script> with a src="", the content of <script>...</script> can only be comments.

[13:32:01.0000] <espadrine>
Is this implemented in major browsers?

[13:32:02.0000] <Philip`>
espadrine: That is purely an authoring conformance requirement, it doesn't affect browsers

[13:33:00.0000] <Philip`>
(Browsers don't run the content of the script element at all, regardless of what's in there, if it has a src attribute)

[13:34:00.0000] <espadrine>
Philip`: ok. Makes sense.

[13:34:01.0000] <Philip`>
(The requirement is there as a way of warning authors when they think they've written script code that will get executed but won't)

[13:34:02.0000] <espadrine>
Do you still get it through script.text though?

[13:34:03.0000] <Philip`>
(without making loads of existing pages that put comments inside scripts non-conforming)

[13:34:04.0000] <Ms2ger>
Yep

[14:06:00.0000] <zcorpan>
smaug____: what would you want to change with message channels?

[14:08:00.0000] <smaug____>

[14:09:00.0000] <smaug____>

[14:10:00.0000] <zcorpan>

[14:10:01.0000] <smaug____>

[14:12:00.0000] <zcorpan>

[14:12:01.0000] <smaug____>

[14:18:00.0000] <smaug____>
the whole port transfer is quite awkward

[14:18:01.0000] <zcorpan>

[14:19:00.0000] <zcorpan>

[14:19:01.0000] <zcorpan>

[14:19:02.0000] <smaug____>
well, just create a new port and the other end could get "connect" event which had .port as a property

[14:31:00.0000] <smaug____>
Hixie: ping

[14:54:00.0000] <Hixie>
smaug____: pong

[14:55:00.0000] <smaug____>
Hixie: what is the use case for MessageChannel?

[14:55:01.0000] <smaug____>
why not just create ports on both sides

[14:55:02.0000] <Hixie>
both sides of what?

[14:55:03.0000] <Hixie>
the use case is the capabilities model. bascially the ability to send someone an API endpoint.

[14:55:04.0000] <smaug____>
but why?

[14:56:00.0000] <Hixie>
why what?

[14:56:01.0000] <smaug____>
why you need the ability to send API endpoint

[14:56:02.0000] <smaug____>
why couldn't you just create end point on both sides

[14:56:03.0000] <Hixie>
both sides of what??

[14:56:04.0000] <smaug____>
say, you have two windows...

[14:57:00.0000] <smaug____>
var port = otherWindow.createPort("name-of-the-port"); // this would cause "connect" event in the otherWindow

[14:57:01.0000] <smaug____>
similar could work with workers

[14:57:02.0000] <Hixie>
you don't know how you've got on the other end, that's the whole point

[14:57:03.0000] <Hixie>
say you are providing an API to, I dunno, add someone to a contact list

[14:58:00.0000] <Hixie>
say you're a webmail app

[14:58:01.0000] <Hixie>
and you have a contact list

[14:58:02.0000] <Hixie>
and the contact list has an API, and one of the operations is "add someone to the contact list"

[14:58:03.0000] <smaug____>
and?

[14:58:04.0000] <Hixie>
if another part of the app wants to add someone to the contact list, they could get the local contacts API object, and then ask it to add to the contac tlist

[14:59:00.0000] <Hixie>
but what if the contact list wants to be implemented in another thread?

[14:59:01.0000] <Hixie>
now the contact API has to proxy everything though

[14:59:02.0000] <Hixie>
what if it's in another domain? now you have to proxy through to an iframe and then from there to the worker, etc

[15:00:00.0000] <Hixie>
now say that the contact list wants to grant the original user of this API the right to delete the user they added, but no other

[15:00:01.0000] <Hixie>
how would you do it?

[15:00:02.0000] <Hixie>
with message channels, you can do all this trivially.

[15:00:03.0000] <Hixie>
there's no need to proxy anything -- the messages just end up at the right end point

[15:00:04.0000] <smaug____>
ah, you want to move the port first via window level postMessage and then post it to a worker?

[15:01:00.0000] <Hixie>
there's no need to worry about permissions, you just give back a port and then whoever has that port can just delete that one contact.

[15:01:01.0000] <Hixie>
etc.

[15:01:02.0000] <Hixie>
for example, yeah

[15:01:03.0000] <Hixie>
this is just a specific example of the capabilities programming model

[15:01:04.0000] <Hixie>
it's like functional programming, it's just a style

[15:01:05.0000] <Hixie>
i mean it's like saying "what's the use case for functions being first-class objects"

[15:01:06.0000] <Hixie>
or "what's the use case for object-orientated programming"

[15:02:00.0000] <smaug____>
it is just quite awkward

[15:02:01.0000] <Hixie>
it's just another tool

[15:03:00.0000] <Hixie>
(a very powerful one, much like oop and lambdas)

[15:03:01.0000] <Hixie>
how is it awkward?

[15:03:02.0000] <smaug____>
when for common cases creating ports could be enough

[15:03:03.0000] <smaug____>
no need to transfer anything

[15:03:04.0000] <Hixie>
?

[15:03:05.0000] <smaug____>
but ok, what you explained is something which isn't clear when reading the drafts

[15:04:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah the drafts assume you know this programming style and that you'll recognise it :-)

[15:04:01.0000] <Hixie>
i should probably have an intro section that explains it or something

[15:04:02.0000] <Hixie>
but i'm not good at explaining it

[15:04:03.0000] <smaug____>
Also, "objects listed in transfer have already been transfered once before, then throw a DATA_CLONE_ERR exception and abort these steps" is easy to misread

[15:05:00.0000] <smaug____>
since I wasn't sure whether one can re-transfer a port

[15:05:01.0000] <Hixie>
that refers to the objects, not the underlying port, but yeah, i see what you mean

[15:06:00.0000] <smaug____>
I still don't see the need to MessageChannel

[15:06:01.0000] <smaug____>
for

[15:06:02.0000] <smaug____>
If one could create ports using createPort or such

[15:06:03.0000] <Hixie>
createPort === MessageChannel

[15:06:04.0000] <smaug____>
very much so

[15:06:05.0000] <Hixie>
MessageChannel is nothing but a port constructor

[15:07:00.0000] <smaug____>
and a bit strange one

[15:07:01.0000] <smaug____>
since I the idea is that the other port is sent to somewhere

[15:07:02.0000] <Hixie>
are you familiar with unix socket programming?

[15:07:03.0000] <smaug____>
yes

[15:07:04.0000] <Hixie>
think of ports as pipes.

[15:07:05.0000] <Hixie>
or rather, sockets

[15:08:00.0000] <Hixie>
when you create a pipe (two sockets) you get both end points

[15:08:01.0000] <smaug____>
sure

[15:08:02.0000] <Hixie>
in exactly the way MessageChannel gives you two ports

[15:08:03.0000] <Hixie>
this is just trying to bring that programming model to JS authors

[15:08:04.0000] <smaug____>
but why do you need both ends

[15:08:05.0000] <smaug____>
when you're going to use one end in one context and the other some other context

[15:11:00.0000] <Hixie>
i don't understand the question

[15:11:01.0000] <smaug____>
MessageChannel creates two ports in the same context

[15:11:02.0000] <smaug____>
and then usually, I assume, the other port is sent to otherWindow or worker or whatever

[15:11:03.0000] <smaug____>
right?

[15:11:04.0000] <Hixie>
it can be, doesn't have to be

[15:11:05.0000] <smaug____>
but that is the basic use case, right?

[15:11:06.0000] <Hixie>
just like when you create a pipe you often pass one socket to somewhere else

[15:12:00.0000] <smaug____>
Why couldn't you just call otherWindow.createPort() which would create one end in the executing context and one port in otherWindow

[15:12:01.0000] <smaug____>
if you really want to, you could call window.createPort()

[15:12:02.0000] <Hixie>
so you'd have otherWindow.createPort, worker.createPort, port.createPort, etc?

[15:12:03.0000] <smaug____>
yes

[15:13:00.0000] <Hixie>
that would be like having Object.addFunction, Array.addFunction, String.addFunction, etc, instead of having a Function constructor

[15:13:01.0000] <Hixie>
i mean i guess it's fine, but it's certainly not what i would describe as neat orthogonal api design

[15:13:02.0000] <smaug____>
that would be like having addEventListener in all the EventTarget objects

[15:14:00.0000] <Hixie>
no, addEventListener() doesn't create anything

[15:15:00.0000] <smaug____>
actually, window, worker and port should all inherit, if possible, some comment base interface

[15:15:01.0000] <smaug____>
s/comment/common/

[15:15:02.0000] <Hixie>
well they all inherit from EventTarget now so that's not an option anymore

[15:15:03.0000] <smaug____>
you could add something between eventtarget and the current interface :)

[15:15:04.0000] <Hixie>
anyway sometimes you just want a standalone message channel because you're goign to be passing it to a callback

[15:16:00.0000] <Hixie>
the fact that you're going to send the port to someone else is not something you should need to care about when you're creating the port

[15:16:01.0000] <Hixie>
the port itself is just a capability endpoint

[15:16:02.0000] <Hixie>
you might keep it in your context, or you might not

[15:16:03.0000] <Hixie>
that's besides the point

[15:17:00.0000] <zewt>
passing them around with structured clone also means you're passing them around with an existing communications interface, rather than defining a separate event

[15:18:00.0000] <smaug____>
I thought the point is to create communication channels between different "contexts"

[15:18:01.0000] <zewt>
eg. so you can receive a message { type: "email", target: "user⊙ec", portForThisInterface: aMessagePort }

[15:19:00.0000] <Hixie>
smaug____: no, the point is to create a capability token.

[15:19:01.0000] <smaug____>
huh

[15:19:02.0000] <Hixie>
smaug____: it just so happens that many times, this will be used in a different context, because in the same context you could get the same effect with a simple function reference

[15:19:03.0000] <smaug____>
anyway, as of now, I don't think we have plans to implement MessageChannels

[15:20:00.0000] <Hixie>
the capability programming people will be sad

[15:23:00.0000] <smaug____>
and, for the common case createPort would make more sense

[15:23:01.0000] <Hixie>
common case of what?

[15:23:02.0000] <zewt>
smaug: not really

[15:23:03.0000] <smaug____>
that you want to enable communication between two different contexts

[15:23:04.0000] <Hixie>
no

[15:23:05.0000] <Hixie>
capability tokens aren't about communicating between different contexts

[15:24:00.0000] <zewt>
it'd separate port creation from other messages, so if you want to create a port with other information attached to it (a description of the port so the other side knows what to do with it), you'd end up duplicating messaging functionality

[15:24:01.0000] <Hixie>
any more than object orientated programming is about, say, allocating memory. or function dispatch.

[15:24:02.0000] <Hixie>
they're related, but that's no the point of the feature.

[15:24:03.0000] <smaug____>
in practice port is all about communication, like sockets

[15:25:00.0000] <Hixie>
i would imagine that most people writing code that creates capability tokens have the code creating the token quite separate from the communication bootstrapping code

[15:29:00.0000] <smaug____>
/me disagrees, but knew that trying get rid of MessageChannel would be hard :)

[15:29:01.0000] <Hixie>
you didn't even know what capability tokens were an hour ago, i don't think you have much credibility in terms of opinions on how caps programming is done :-P

[15:30:00.0000] <smaug____>
that is not the point

[15:30:01.0000] <smaug____>
the point is to have easy to use APIs for web devs

[15:33:00.0000] <Hixie>
i'm sure we can all agree on that point

[15:39:00.0000] <Hixie>
if anyone has opinions on http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=12306 it would be helpful if you could put them in the bug. Right now I'm leaning towards leaving the MUST in, which makes a lot of <canvas>-based apps non-conforming currently (especially games).

[15:41:00.0000] <Hixie>
hober: any chance we can get the csswg to use bugzilla?

[15:43:00.0000] <jgraham>
Hixie: I think that bug is angels on the head os a pin stuff that will have no effect on any part of the real world. So I wouldn't spend any time on it

[15:43:01.0000] <jgraham>
I also agree that having to pass around message ports seems weirdly cumbersome, but it does sound quite powerful

[15:46:00.0000] <Hixie>
unless you're using their power, you're really not going to need to send them over at all, as far as i can tell. for example workers create them implicitly.

[15:46:01.0000] <jgraham>

[15:46:02.0000] <Hixie>

[15:46:03.0000] <Hixie>

[15:47:02.0000] <jgraham>

[15:49:00.0000] <Hixie>

[15:49:01.0000] <jgraham>

[15:49:02.0000] <Hixie>
i do not recall one way or the other

[15:49:03.0000] <Hixie>
if it's implemented i don't intend to change it

[15:50:00.0000] <jgraham>

[15:50:01.0000] <jgraham>
I have no idea if this is implemented

[15:50:02.0000] <jgraham>
Presumably it is webkit-only if it is

[15:51:00.0000] <Hixie>
what's the order and what do you want it to do?

[15:52:00.0000] <jgraham>
(quantum entanglement seems rather different because the entangled parts resolve into different states as needed to preserve physical invariants. Whereas here the ports presumably have the same information on both ends)

[15:53:00.0000] <jgraham>
I just mean taht postMessage(message, ports, targetOrigin) seems inconsistent with postMessage(message, targetOrigin)

[15:53:01.0000] <jgraham>
I would expect the additional argument to be last

[18:06:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Cross-origin XHR is completely disallowed, right?  Even just sending the request, not just receiving the response?

[18:09:00.0000] <jamesr>
sicking: you there?

[18:10:00.0000] <sicking>
jamesr: yo

[18:10:01.0000] <sicking>
TabAtkins: how do you mean?

[18:10:02.0000] <sicking>
TabAtkins: you can do cross-origin XHR using CORS

[18:10:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Right, but outside of that it's disallowed.

[18:10:04.0000] <sicking>
TabAtkins: which means that you can make the request in many cases without the server opting in

[18:11:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
sicking: What do you mean?  What I'm asking about is using XHR to send data from client->server only, not caring about the response back.

[18:11:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
(Actually asking about a different API that effectively accomplishes that.)

[18:12:00.0000] <sicking>
TabAtkins: yup, you can basically do that, as long as you use POST with a limited set of Content-Types

[18:12:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Without having to invoke CORS?

[18:12:02.0000] <sicking>
well, it invokes CORS

[18:12:03.0000] <sicking>
but CORS doesn't do anything until it start receiving a response

[18:13:00.0000] <sicking>
since CORS is response-header based

[18:13:01.0000] <sicking>
note, that you can only do this if your POST is fairly "plain"

[18:13:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's what I thought.  So the actual message from client->server gets through regardless.

[18:13:03.0000] <sicking>
i.e. you can't set any custom headers

[18:13:04.0000] <sicking>
TabAtkins: yup

[18:13:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
kk.

[18:13:06.0000] <sicking>
TabAtkins: just like with <form>

[18:14:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
All right, cool.

[18:15:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
(Context is someone pinging me about the feasibility of a built-in bugreporting function, that lets you specify a url to post to, some custom data to send, and a list of UA-provided data that you'd like, so the browser can let the user decide what to send and then post for you.)

[18:15:01.0000] <jamesr>
sicking: for XHR 'text' can be considered a parsed format

[18:16:00.0000] <jamesr>
sicking: what happens if the text is encoded in utf-8 and only part of the codepoint sequence (or whatever unicode calls it) is in the most recently received packet?

[18:16:01.0000] <sicking>
jamesr: then you don't return that character until in the next progress notification

[18:16:02.0000] <jamesr>
but the idea is the browser could ditch most of the response?

[18:16:03.0000] <sicking>
jamesr: yup

[18:17:00.0000] <sicking>
all but the last few bytes

[18:18:00.0000] <jamesr>
would be nice

[18:18:01.0000] <sicking>
TabAtkins: just make sure to not even return a error code indicating if the submission succeeded or not

[18:18:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Ah, good point.

[18:19:00.0000] <jamesr>
what happens if you try to set .responseType after receiving a few progress events? it throws an error?

[18:19:01.0000] <sicking>
yes, that's already the case

[00:40:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

how can you cause corruption in another _process_?

[15:15:02.0000] <Hixie>
don't modern OSes pretty much make that impossible?

[15:15:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Dont' ask me.  I'm recalling lunchtime conversation.

[15:16:00.0000] <Hixie>
if the problem is other code in the _same_ process randomly stomping on the space used by the sqlite library, it seems any library would suffer the same problem

[15:16:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hixie, maybe when two processes have the same database file open and one writes to it in a way that's not coordinated with the other, so the other winds up reading garbage somehow?

[15:17:00.0000] <Hixie>
that'd be a bug in sqlite's locking

[15:17:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I thought only one process can open an SQLite database at a time, though.

[15:17:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yeah, I dunno.

[15:17:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: It wasn't sqlite's problem directly; it was definitely memory corruption coming from elsewhere.

[15:18:00.0000] <zewt>
so it's very wrong to say "sqlite has corruption issues"

[15:18:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah i don't see why sqlite would be any more at risk than leveldb

[15:19:00.0000] <Hixie>
but what do i know :-)

[15:19:01.0000] <zewt>
which I doubt anyone would accept anyway; sqlite should be high on any competent programmer's top-five list of most reliable libraries in the world

[15:20:00.0000] <karlcow>
the storage library the highest on my list is definitely… my fridge!

[15:20:01.0000] <karlcow>
every day, a few times a day.

[15:21:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
zewt: From the conversation I had with a guy working on indexeddb, sqlite made some not-strictly-required architectural decisions that mean that it holds its memory for too long, making it more subject to this kind of corruption.

[15:22:00.0000] <zewt>
sounds like a very contrived argument

[15:22:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I may be misstating things.

[15:22:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
zewt: I'm not sure what you're trying to imply.  We used sqlite.  We had regular db corruption.  We traced it to a problem with the design of sqlite.

[15:23:00.0000] <jgraham>
It seems to me that "it's not designed to be a k-v store" might be a god enough reason on its own to think about other solutions for indexeddb

[15:23:01.0000] <jgraham>
*good

[15:23:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
I'm not saying sqlite is horrible.  I'm saying it didn't suit our needs, so we designed a new one.

[15:23:03.0000] <jamesr>
i don't think the primary motivation for leveldb was sqlite db corruption bugs

[15:23:04.0000] <jamesr>
although it may have been one

[15:23:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
jgraham: Indeed, that too.

[15:23:06.0000] <jamesr>
jgraham: exactly

[15:23:07.0000] <zewt>
... if library X writes to random memory locations and corrupts memory owned by library Y, it is not in any conceivable sense library Y's fault for "holding that memory for too long"

[15:23:08.0000] <TabAtkins>
jamesr: It was the reason that FileSystem is switching from sqlite to leveldb, at least.

[15:23:09.0000] <zewt>
"i shot some bullets down the street and someone got hit, it's hit fault for standing there for so long"

[15:23:10.0000] <Philip`>
Most databases have a separate server process, so only bugs in that process could scribble over the database, whereas SQLite runs in the address space of the host application so it's vulnerable to bugs in any applications that touch the database

[15:24:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
zewt: Robustness.  If Y can avoid a lot of those problems, but it doesn't, then that's a problem.

[15:24:01.0000] <Philip`>
though LevelDB seems to be embedded in applications too so it'd be just as vulnerable

[15:24:02.0000] <zewt>
avoid problems caused by unrelated code smashing memory? sorry, that's utter nonsense

[15:24:03.0000] <gsnedders>
TabAtkins: Why have there not been issues with corruptions with the insane number of other people using SqLite3?

[15:24:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
zewt: I'm not blaming anybody, so don't treat it as a personal attack.  I'm saying that we needed something that didn't stand in the street quite so long.

[15:24:05.0000] <zewt>
problems caused by code smashing random memory (or whatever) is the fault of that code and that code alone

[15:24:06.0000] <karlcow>
http://google-opensource.blogspot.com/2011/07/leveldb-fast-persistent-key-value-store.html

[15:25:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
gsnedders: No clue.  Again, I'm relaying lunchtime conversation.

[15:25:01.0000] <zewt>
i'm not treating anything as a personal attack; i have nothing to do with sqlite development

[15:25:02.0000] <karlcow>
http://leveldb.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/doc/benchmark.html

[15:25:03.0000] <zewt>
i'm saying it's a ridiculous, nonsensical reason to change libraries.

[15:25:04.0000] <Hixie>
either it's a bug in sqlite that should be fixed, or it's a bug in the surrounding code and leveldb would be equally vulnerable, as far as i can tell

[15:25:05.0000] <jamesr>
no, there were others

[15:25:06.0000] <TabAtkins>
zewt: If you're shooting bullets into the street, it's your fault when you hit somebody.  But if you're relying on something that needs to cross the street, it's better to rely on one that won't spend as long in the crossfire.

[15:26:00.0000] <jgraham>
Quick to the car metaphors!

[15:26:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Car metaphors explains EVERYTHING.

[15:26:02.0000] <jgraham>
+,

[15:26:03.0000] <zewt>
changing libraries means whoever's firing the bullets is going to be hitting other things, and it'll be some other random piece of code being broken

[15:27:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
zewt: ...yes?  And with luck, it'll be something that doesn't lose long-term data when it errors out.

[15:27:01.0000] <Hixie>
luck seems like a rather crappy design philosophy :-)

[15:27:02.0000] <zewt>
it's just nonsense FUD that'll lead less experienced developers to believe that "leveldb" (whatever that is) is more reliable than sqlite, which is bogus

[15:27:03.0000] <jamesr>
i'm pretty sure that leveldb is no safer to memory corruption in your process than anything else

[15:28:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah i don't see how it could be

[15:28:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
zewt: Argh, I'm saying, very specifically, that one of *our* teams is running into this problem with sqlite, and is switching to leveldb because it fixes the architectural issue.

[15:28:02.0000] <zewt>
if you really want to protect from corruption, move your sqlite access into a helper process and proxy SQL commands to it

[15:28:03.0000] <jgraham>
/me thinks that having arguments based on half-remembered lunch conversations using metaphors involving violent death is probably not the road to enlightenment

[15:28:04.0000] <zewt>

[15:29:00.0000] <zewt>

[15:29:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

[10:53:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: Argh, worst is the OMGWTFBBQ about self-signed certs.  Not even a whisper of complaint when you visit a page that does login over HTTP POST, but if you *dare* to try to secure the connection without going through the registrar mafia?  RED PAGE.

[10:53:05.0000] <timeless>
AryehGregor: there's sconnect or something for ssl

[10:54:00.0000] <timeless>
i've used that as a telnet replacement for https

[10:54:01.0000] <zewt>
tab: yeah, i've been ranting for a while about the ridiculousness of browsers training people to think of unsigned encryption as *less* secure than plaintext

[10:54:02.0000] <zewt>
i understand the rationale, but the end result is no less absurd for it

[10:54:03.0000] <timeless>
zewt: well

[10:55:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I don't even understand the rationale.

[10:55:01.0000] <timeless>
the rationale is:

[10:55:02.0000] <timeless>
if you normally don't get an error

[10:55:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
You don't trust the endpoint, but you trust the connection.

[10:55:04.0000] <timeless>
then when you do get an error, you're probably being attacked

[10:55:05.0000] <zewt>
the rationale is that you don't want people loading their https://bank.com and having an attacker present the site with a self-signed cert

[10:55:06.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's better than trusting neither.

[10:55:07.0000] <timeless>
whereas if you are visiting a site that never pretends to be secure

[10:55:08.0000] <timeless>
then you're supposed to know that it isn't necessarily trustworthy

[10:55:09.0000] <timeless>
but you also know that there's no reason to consider today any more or less different from yesterday

[10:56:00.0000] <timeless>
the big problem is...

[10:56:01.0000] <timeless>
banks offer http://bank.com

[10:56:02.0000] <timeless>
and often have login pages on that page

[10:56:03.0000] <zewt>
the solution, IMO, is/was/should have been to have an shttp:// protocol, which is exactly identical to https but without the certificate check, so loading https URLs can't be compromised in that way, while still allowing people to use encryption without a cert

[10:56:04.0000] <timeless>
which teach users to enter their credentials *there*!

[10:57:00.0000] <timeless>
zewt: for what purpose?

[10:57:01.0000] <zewt>
i've never seen a bank with a login not on https (of course I only use my bank), but my electric or gas company (forget which) has a login on http (with some dumb flash hack to handle the actual encryption)

[10:57:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, https:// with self-signed cert is, in general, worse than http://.

[10:57:03.0000] <zewt>
timeless: huh? for the purpose of encrypting :)

[10:57:04.0000] <timeless>
zewt: try http://www.discovercard.com/

[10:57:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me digs up rationale

[10:57:06.0000] <timeless>
there's a login form on that page

[10:57:07.0000] <timeless>
i've actually done surveys of banks

[10:57:08.0000] <timeless>
and it varies by size and region

[10:57:09.0000] <timeless>
but there are definitely plenty of banks w/ login forms on their front page (which is http)

[10:57:10.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, http://lwn.net/Articles/413600/

[10:58:00.0000] <timeless>
and please note that having a phone number or hours/addresses on http is also bad

[10:58:01.0000] <zewt>
if there was an http* protocol meant for encryption-without-certs, every webserver in the world would ship with a default configuration allowing encryption, and the level of security in the world would be a notch higher

[10:58:02.0000] <swarren08>
wow...  people will do anything to hack you

[10:58:03.0000] <timeless>
if i'm using an internet cafe in a foreign country

[10:58:04.0000] <timeless>
i can easily be tricked into going to a fake bank or fake atm

[10:58:05.0000] <timeless>

[10:58:06.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me <3 Google for giving his post as the first result for "lwn.net Simetrical self-signed"

[10:58:07.0000] <zewt>
it would not be a *lot* higher, since it obviously wouldn't protect against MITM, but the world would be substantially less susceptible to passive sniffing

[10:58:08.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: Yes, the confusion angle is the only thing.  Presenting the same UI for a self-signed and an EV-signed would be bad.

[10:58:09.0000] <AryehGregor>
zewt, tcpcrypt.org is a very neat technology.

[10:59:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[10:59:01.0000] <timeless>
passive sniffing is kinda useless as risks go

[10:59:02.0000] <timeless>
if i'm in an internet cafe

[10:59:03.0000] <swarren08>

[10:59:04.0000] <zewt>
spdy is also always encrypted, signed or no

[10:59:05.0000] <zewt>
iirc

[10:59:06.0000] <timeless>
there's really no way to protect me from a MITM

[10:59:07.0000] <AryehGregor>
tcpcrypt covers all TCP, though.

[10:59:08.0000] <timeless>
and that MITM becomes equivalent to passive snooping

[10:59:09.0000] <AryehGregor>
SPDY is always encrypted because it has to tunnel through HTTP proxies that try to meddle with regular HTTP.

[10:59:10.0000] <zewt>
mitm is ... the opposite of passive

[11:00:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
No, MITM can include passive as well as active.

[11:00:01.0000] <timeless>
you might as well get people to do the right thing and have good certs

[11:00:02.0000] <swarren08>
People go thru and do a web site dump of the Official site

[11:00:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Generally any time you can do passive you can do active, but active is often harder to pull off and/or carries more risk of detection.

[11:00:04.0000] <swarren08>
and adjust it to the site they own, make own certs and send the links to people

[11:00:05.0000] <timeless>
/me notes that there are deployed attacks which actually do this

[11:00:06.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: Thanks for reminding me about tcpcrypt.  I meant to install it last time I saw it.

[11:01:00.0000] <timeless>
they've even been described on krebsonsecurity.com

[11:01:01.0000] <swarren08>
they are able to take over what they want and also capture the accounts of people

[11:01:02.0000] <zewt>
active is by nature riskier, which is a deterrant by itself

[11:01:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
tcpcrypt is clever that way: you don't know whether there will be authentication until the encryption is finished.  So a MITM has to decide whether to intercept the connection before knowing if they'll be detected.  If you have auth layered on top of tcpcrypt or similar, the attacker will intercept it fine, but then the authentication will fail and the attacker will be detected.

[11:01:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
In principle, if tcpcrypt were deployed, you could do things like expose the client's session id to JavaScript, say.

[11:02:00.0000] <timeless>
err

[11:02:01.0000] <timeless>
can't the server expose that already?

[11:02:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
So the server could send some code with the server's session id somewhere and check it against the client id.  The attacker could theoretically rewrite the code to prevent that, but not in general -- it's the halting problem.

[11:02:03.0000] <timeless>
oh

[11:02:04.0000] <timeless>
well

[11:02:05.0000] <timeless>
no

[11:03:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
So the attacker could have special hacks to rewrite the checks for known apps, but some random webpage that does it in some slightly different way would still be able to throw up a scary error.

[11:03:01.0000] <timeless>
MITM could pretty trivially include code which tries to capture access to a property

[11:03:02.0000] <zewt>
AryehGregor: don't know how you mean that MITM can be done passively; the definition of MITM is active, sending packets to one or both parties

[11:03:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
timeless, you could make the property a non-replaceable global so that nothing can capture access to it.

[11:03:04.0000] <zewt>
(most often both, hence the term)

[11:03:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
zewt, it can include interception as well, AFAIK.  MITMs can merely eavesdrop.

[11:04:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hmm, I see.

[11:04:01.0000] <zewt>
eavesdropping isn't MITM, it's sniffing

[11:04:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, an MITM is perhaps always active to some extent, but not necessarily in a noticeable fashion.

[11:04:03.0000] <timeless>
AryehGregor: at that point, the attacker will just rewrite all streams looking for the keyword, replace `eval`, and rewrite any instance of `window` to an object which does shadowing

[11:04:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
A compromised router is a MITM.

[11:04:05.0000] <zewt>
depends on the particular attack

[11:04:06.0000] <AryehGregor>
But it might just be sniffing traffic, not doing anything discernibly wrong.

[11:04:07.0000] <timeless>
i wonder if someone has a toolkit that does that

[11:04:08.0000] <zewt>
a compromised router is a MITM if you're using it to sit between and manipulate the two endpoints

[11:05:00.0000] <zewt>
ngrep on a compromised router is not MITM

[11:05:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
timeless, hmm, I guess.  You could make it a magic keyword, but then they could sniff for a keyword.

[11:05:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Anyway, it would be a way to catch attackers who aren't careful.

[11:05:03.0000] <timeless>
yep

[11:05:04.0000] <timeless>
AryehGregor: the problem is...

[11:05:05.0000] <timeless>
attackers will share toolkits

[11:05:06.0000] <AryehGregor>
zewt, definitionally, I disagree, but it's semantics, so whatever.

[11:05:07.0000] <timeless>
which means the X months it takes to deploy a security feature

[11:05:08.0000] <AryehGregor>
timeless, sophisticated ones will.  Script kiddies will use whatever they happen to get off the shelf, which may or may not be competently written depending on their connections and price range.

[11:05:09.0000] <zewt>
mitm is a specific term referring to a specific class of attacks

[11:06:00.0000] <timeless>
will be defeated in X/12 months and then shared

[11:06:01.0000] <timeless>
it will appear in the script kiddy toolkits in 3/7 * X months

[11:06:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yeah, it's just a speed bump.  But it will catch some attacks.

[11:06:03.0000] <timeless>
it really isn't a useful speed bump

[11:06:04.0000] <timeless>
and it's somewhat expensive to implement

[11:06:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's basically free to implement, given that tcpcrypt is already being used.

[11:06:06.0000] <timeless>
cost benefit there is terrible

[11:07:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Which is a good idea anyway to stop sniffers.

[11:08:00.0000] <timeless>
what protects tcpcrypt from a mitm that always claims not to support tcpcrypt?

[11:08:01.0000] <timeless>
(standard downgrade attack)

[11:09:00.0000] <timeless>
/me hunts lunch

[11:10:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
timeless, such a MITM could also just intercept the connection directly.  So there's no added threat surface.

[11:11:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Either way, it forces them to become an active attacker -- they can't just sniff.

[11:11:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Also, tcpcrypt exposes a very nice, useful primitive (session id) that you can trivially layer authentication on top of.

[11:11:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
So it would allow a lot of code to be unified that currently has to be redone for every different application-level protocol.

[11:49:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[11:49:05.0000] <Philip`>

[11:50:00.0000] <gesa>

[11:51:00.0000] <GlitchMr>
Browsers don't understand /> in SGML mode. Only while parsing documents as XML. Otherwise, they consider that / is just some random character to ignore.

[11:51:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
s/SGML/HTML/

[11:52:00.0000] <Ms2ger>
Nah

[11:52:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
In SGML mode, the / closes the tag, and the > is part of the text content.  Luckily, no one's been an SGML browser for some time.

[11:52:02.0000] <GlitchMr>
Oh, right. Browsers fail at SHML. They don't know that <br/> in actually <br> and after that &gt; character...

[11:52:03.0000] <Ms2ger>
They acknowledge the trailing solidus

[11:54:00.0000] <Philip`>
TabAtkins: No one except the W3C validator, which will happily parse your document completely differently to any real browser before validating the result

[11:54:01.0000] <GlitchMr>
I remember <!-- -- >The comment is closed :). Browsers implemented it for some time just because of ACID2...

[11:55:00.0000] <GlitchMr>
W3C Validator is lame for me anyways. It doesn't take into account real problems and it blatantly accepts markup like <h1><ins><h2><del><h3></h3></del></h2></ins></h1>.

[11:56:00.0000] <GlitchMr>
And it's not error in validator :P. HTML shouldn't be parsed using DTD.

[06:00:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Still sad the reason why it had to get into the spec. :( (The only mostly standards based code-path on Yahoo Mail is the Gecko one — both the WebKit and IE ones rely on non-standard stuff — so for any other browser to be competitive you have to implement the only-just-being-specced HTMLUnknownElement, XMLParser, and DOMSerializer, and change your UA string to pretend to be Firefox.)

[06:00:01.0000] <gsnedders>
(And people care about Yahoo Mail, so you have to support one of their three browser-specific code-paths)

[06:03:00.0000] <roc>
what non-standard stuff does the Webkit code path use?

[06:03:01.0000] <gsnedders>
roc: I forget — it was quite a long time since I looked at it

[06:14:00.0000] <gsnedders>
roc: Digging through bugs, I think it was relying on things like exact innerHTML serialization, random edge-cases around ranges.

[06:14:01.0000] <gsnedders>
(And, uh, it appears what eventually launched at the new Yahoo Mail supports us, if I understand correctly.)

[06:15:00.0000] <roc>
we should be able to get around those issues as the specs tighten up and Webkit fixes their bugs

[06:15:01.0000] <gsnedders>
roc: Yeah, indeed

[06:15:02.0000] <roc>
I'd be more worried if they were using Webkit-prefixed features or Web SQL DB or something

[06:16:00.0000] <gsnedders>
roc: We support Web SQL DB, so I probably wouldn't have noticed.

[06:16:01.0000] <roc>
*I'd* have been more worried :-)

[06:16:02.0000] <gsnedders>

[06:16:03.0000] <gsnedders>

[06:17:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[06:17:01.0000] <Ms2ger>

[06:17:02.0000] <roc>

[06:17:03.0000] <gsnedders>

[06:18:00.0000] <Ms2ger>
What, NaCl?

[06:19:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Most things have four code-paths: an IE one relying upon loads of IE bugs; a Gecko one using lots of Gecko-prefixed stuff; a WebKit one using lots of WebKit-prefixed stuff; and an Opera one using lots of Opera-prefixed stuff (and historically relying upon random bugs too, though we've managed to get rid of the worst of that to fix the bugs).

[06:19:01.0000] <gsnedders>
If you want to bring a new engine to market, you're pretty much fucked by Google.

[06:20:00.0000] <Ms2ger>

[01:06:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
question about the Do Not Track feature/spec, for anybody who knows

[01:06:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
if I send a DNT: 1 opt-out header to "first-party" site, does that mean it also can't do any "collection, retention, and use of all data related  to the request and response"?

[01:07:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
or does it mean only any third-party sites with embedded content on that page can't do collection, retention, and use of all data related to the request and response?

[01:07:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
it's not clear from the spec

[01:07:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-mayer-do-not-track-00

[01:08:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
the spec says, "In processing a request that includes an OPT-OUT header, a server MUST NOT perform THIRD-PARTY TRACKING"

[01:09:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
but it doesn't say the first-party site can't do "tracking" (= collection, retention, and use of all data related to the request and response)

[01:10:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
and given a request with a DNT: 1 header, how does a site know whether it's a third-party site or a first-party site?

[01:14:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
or does the UA only send the DNT: 1 header to third-party sites but not not first-party sites?

[01:58:00.0000] <zcorpan>

[07:38:01.0000] <annevk>

[07:38:02.0000] <annevk>

[07:40:00.0000] <jarek>

[07:42:02.0000] <annevk>

[07:50:00.0000] <jarek>
CSS3 media queries specification says that resolution may accept only dpi and dpcm units and that resolution property applies to bitmap media types

[07:50:01.0000] <jarek>
now CSS2 specs defines bitmap media types as:

[07:51:00.0000] <jarek>
print, projection, screen and tv

[07:51:01.0000] <jarek>
I guess this means that DPI should be treated as PPI

[07:52:00.0000] <jarek>
at least on screen

[07:52:01.0000] <annevk>
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dots_per_inch#Computer_monitor_DPI_standards

[07:54:00.0000] <annevk>
yay, WHATWG Blog has >6000 subscribers per Google Reader

[07:58:03.0000] <jarek>

[08:00:00.0000] <jarek>

[08:01:00.0000] <Philip`>
There's the number of RGB cells per inch on your LCD screen, and the number of pixels of data that the computer sends to the display per cell (hence per inch), and the number of pixels of data that the computer uses to represent objects measured in inches (or in fractions of inches, e.g. points)

[08:02:00.0000] <Philip`>
plus any scaling factors the software wants to add

[08:03:00.0000] <Philip`>
Also, the length of an inch will change if you travel at relativistic speeds

[08:03:01.0000] <Philip`>
So it's quite hard to be consistent about measurements

[08:04:00.0000] <jarek>

[09:14:00.0000] <annevk>

[09:14:01.0000] <annevk>

[09:14:02.0000] <volkmar>

[09:15:00.0000] <annevk>

[09:15:01.0000] <benjoffe_>

[09:20:00.0000] <volkmar>

[09:20:01.0000] <volkmar>

[09:21:00.0000] <annevk>

[09:22:00.0000] <zewt>
would seem like a very arbitrary special case to not support it

[09:22:01.0000] <annevk>

[09:22:02.0000] <jgraham>
annevk: My concern might be the *if*

[09:23:00.0000] <annevk>
jgraham, then they would have problems with their JavaScript-based solution as well

[09:23:01.0000] <annevk>

[09:23:02.0000] <Philip`>
If you want to support accidental whitespace included around passwords, it'd be just as easy to do the trimming on the server (and then you could check both the trimmed and untrimmed passwords, in case the spaces really are part of the password)

[09:23:03.0000] <zewt>
conversely (though this is all very contrived and I don't see either ever happening in reality) someone might have their site trim spaces when storing a password, and use <input trim> to trim when entering, and not realize the *lack* of side effects due to arbitrary special cases

[09:25:00.0000] <volkmar>
annevk: in general, altering the passwords value seems a wrong idea to me

[09:26:00.0000] <timeless>
yeah, any sanitization really needs to be enforced server side

[09:27:00.0000] <timeless>

[09:29:05.0000] <zewt>

[09:30:00.0000] <zewt>

[09:30:01.0000] <zewt>

[09:30:02.0000] <timeless>

[09:30:03.0000] <timeless>

[09:31:01.0000] <timeless>

[17:02:00.0000] <roc>
Anne's right of course, but this situation is a bit different from line breaking in that with line breaking, there often is no clearly "right" algorithm, but it's pretty clear that shaping across element boundaries *should* work

[17:11:00.0000] <roc>

[12:49:00.0000] <manu-db>
Question about JavaScript APIs spec'd in WebIDL directed at anyone that knows the answer:

[12:49:01.0000] <manu-db>
When processing a part of a DOM or JSON, is it better to return a null value (if there was some sort of processing error), or is it better to raise an exception of some sort?

[12:50:00.0000] <manu-db>
and if it "depends on the application", are there general guidelines?

[12:52:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
manu-db, it depends, and partly it's a matter of taste.  Exceptions cause the whole app to blow up if uncaught, so it's best to only throw them only if the author did something seriously wrong.  Returning null or something is typically a better idea if there's nothing wrong with what the author did, but there's no useful information to return.

[12:52:01.0000] <Hixie>
(of course returing null if the author didn't expect it can quickly turn into an exception too)

[12:53:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
It would be easier to say if you gave a specific example.

[12:53:01.0000] <manu-db>
/me goes to find an example...

[12:53:02.0000] <manu-db>
http://json-ld.org/spec/ED/20110817/#widl-JSONLDProcessor-frame-object-object-input-object-frame-object-options-JSONLDProcessorCallback-callback

[12:53:03.0000] <manu-db>
bleh, that is an awful URL...

[12:54:00.0000] <Ms2ger>
Yes, I was about to mention that :)

[12:54:01.0000] <zewt>
returning null on an error condition isn't very useful--it doesn't say anything about what failed

[12:54:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
It really depends.

[12:55:00.0000] <manu-db>
anyway - the jsonld.frame() call takes a JavaScript object (input) and another JavaScript object (frame) and re-organizes the original input to have a specific structure/hierarchy (based on the frame).

[12:55:01.0000] <Ms2ger>
And what is the error condition you're thinking of?

[12:55:02.0000] <manu-db>
but there are some frames that are just plain invalid.

[12:55:03.0000] <manu-db>
(because keywords were messed up or data is wrong, etc.)

[12:55:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
manu-db, if designing a new API from scratch, I'd usually say to throw an exception if the method was passed invalid/malformed input.

[12:55:05.0000] <Ms2ger>
What he said ^

[12:56:00.0000] <Hixie>
there are varying schools of thought. My main feedback would be that if you pick one, make sure to stick to it so that the API is consistent

[12:56:01.0000] <manu-db>
so, you could answer back with null, which means (you gave us crap... so your output is null) - or you could throw an exception (you gave us crap, your code is busted... fix it)

[12:56:02.0000] <Hixie>
and if people convince you to change from one to the other, make sure to change everything at the same time so it stays consistent :-)

[12:56:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
If the author is passing malformed input to the API, it almost certainly indicates some kind of bug.

[12:57:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
There's no reason you'd want to pass malformed input to this API, right?

[12:57:01.0000] <Hixie>
well it could be user-provided input

[12:57:02.0000] <Hixie>
right?

[12:57:03.0000] <manu-db>
AryehGregor - correct.

[12:57:04.0000] <Ms2ger>
Consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds.

[12:57:05.0000] <Hixie>
that you just didn't check

[12:57:06.0000] <zewt>
returning null for invalid input would be very unusual

[12:57:07.0000] <manu-db>
well, developer provided in this case.

[12:57:08.0000] <Philip`>
If the function just returned null, how would you tell what the error was in the input and how to fix it?

[12:57:09.0000] <AryehGregor>
Right, then you want to do try/catch.

[12:57:10.0000] <Hixie>
Ms2ger: so are cliches :-P

[12:57:11.0000] <manu-db>
I can't think of a use case where it would be user-provided, Hixie...

[12:57:12.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, probably an exception would just be SYNTAX_ERR anyway.

[12:57:13.0000] <Ms2ger>
Hixie, indeed :)

[12:57:14.0000] <zewt>
to little minds, consistency is a hobgoblin

[12:58:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
manu-db, oh, so you'd expect that the correct use of the function would only be to accept input that comes from another function?

[12:58:01.0000] <Ms2ger>
AryehGregor, of course he should invent an exception hierarchy five levels deep

[12:58:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or that was typed manually by the developer?

[12:58:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
In that case, definitely throw.

[12:58:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Invalid input indicates a bug.

[12:58:05.0000] <manu-db>
AryehGregor - correct.

[12:59:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
The only time I'd say not to throw on invalid input is if it's user-provided or something, so it might be invalid even if there are no bugs in the program.

[12:59:01.0000] <zewt>
should throw in that case too, IMO

[12:59:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yeah, I'd usually say to throw then too.

[12:59:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
But there's more of a case for not throwing, because it can cause the program to die.

[12:59:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
If you can handle it gracefully, that might be better.

[12:59:05.0000] <manu-db>
Ok, well - that was all very helpful - thanks AryehGregor, Hixie, Ms2ger, Philip`, zewt

[13:00:00.0000] <zewt>
the error result could do that in any case, if the programmer wasn't aware that it can happen

[13:00:01.0000] <manu-db>
I'll change the API to throw exceptions, consistently, on input that is a syntax error.

[13:00:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
E.g., per my current spec, execCommand() and friends only throw if you call a method on some command where it makes no sense, like asking for the value of bold.

[13:00:03.0000] <zewt>
at least, for things returning a value

[13:00:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
zewt, it depends what you return.  If you're normally going to return an object, yes.  If you're normally returning a string, probably not.

[13:00:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
Particularly not if you return an empty string on error instead of null.

[13:01:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Basically, make it easy to gracefully handle user input errors.

[13:01:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
If possible.

[13:01:02.0000] <zewt>
just seems like a way of masking bugs and making them harder to fix

[13:01:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
zewt, not if the user input is uncommon or unreasonable anyway.  E.g., at one point I had execCommand("insertImage", false, "") (= insert an image with no URL) throw.  Now it just does nothing.

[13:02:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Thus it has no effect, which makes sense, instead of crashing the program.

[13:02:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
That's a reasonable case of graceful error handling.  Throwing wouldn't really help anyone.

[13:02:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Since typically, the URL will be user-provided, and if the user provides the empty string as a URL for some reason, it's not helpful to crash.

[13:03:00.0000] <Philip`>
manu-db: By the way: "The 'input' is used to build the framed output and is returned if there are no errors." sounds like it's returning the 'input' value, which seems kind of redundant - is it meant to say it returns the framed output instead?

[13:03:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Of course a well-designed app will validate the URL to a greater extent than that, but this helps out apps that were written without so much care.

[13:03:02.0000] <zewt>
that's not reporting an error with a mechanism other than exceptions (eg. returning it), though, that's just silently ignoring errors, which is different

[13:04:00.0000] <manu-db>
Philip` the prose is crap right now... gonna make another pass at cleaning it up. But yes, you are right - I'll try to make it more apparent that the input value is being used to generate /something else/ that will be returned by the method.

[13:04:01.0000] <Philip`>
AryehGregor: "crashing the program" seems misleading - more likely it'll just abort the onclick handler of the button the user clicked to insert an image, which isn't a particularly fatal problem

[13:04:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, depends what the onclick handler is doing.

[13:05:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
zewt, yes, true.

[13:12:00.0000] <manu-db>
Got another question for anyone that knows how @lang or @xml:lang is processed in HTML5 across most of the browsers... Ivan reported a bug where the language of a document may not be properly detected if there is a bunch of stuff in the <HTML> element - for example if there are a ton of @xmlns: or @prefix declarations. It seemed as if some of the browsers sniff for the language of the...

[13:12:01.0000] <manu-db>
...document, and if they don't find it in the first 256 bytes (or something like that), they just default to a western character set, which hoses the page.

[13:12:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
IIRC, charset detection isn't very standard right now.  Browsers definitely do charset detection only based on the first handful of bytes, though.

[13:12:03.0000] <manu-db>
This came up because we were thinking of limiting @prefix declarations in RDFa 1.1 to the HTML element... but if this bug exists, we may want to allow @prefix on HTML, HEAD and BODY... instead of all elements.

[13:12:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
As a rule.

[13:13:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
So if they're using lang="" as part of charset detection, that can't be too far into the HTML source.

[13:13:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Same with <meta charset> etc.

[13:13:02.0000] <manu-db>
damn...

[13:13:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
That's because they don't want to get the first packet, start parsing in one charset, then have to throw everything away and start over when they get the second packet.

[13:14:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me wasn't aware of browsers ever using lang for charset detection

[13:14:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
So they only look at a handful of bytes, which will hopefully be in the first packet.

[13:14:02.0000] <manu-db>
is there any effort to spec that in HTML5? This seems to be an issue in any non-western character-set HTML document.

[13:14:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
There's something about it, let me see.

[13:14:04.0000] <manu-db>
hmm... I see.

[13:14:05.0000] <Philip`>
HTML5 says to look in at least the first 1024 bytes for a charset, I think

[13:14:06.0000] <Ms2ger>
I doubt that browsers really use lang

[13:14:07.0000] <manu-db>
Problem is that it totally screws over the non-western charset people.

[13:15:00.0000] <Ms2ger>
Those who still don't use UTF-8?

[13:15:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Basically, everyone should just use UTF-8, yeah.

[13:15:02.0000] <manu-db>
yeah

[13:15:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/parsing.html#determining-the-character-encoding

[13:16:00.0000] <manu-db>
Ms2ger yes it screws over the non-UTF-8 people... but there are quite a number of them (anecdotal)

[13:16:01.0000] <Ms2ger>
And if they insist on something else, there's still the HTPP header

[13:16:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
HTML5 seems not to mandate a specific number of bytes.

[13:16:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
"The user agent may wait for more bytes of the resource to be available, either in this step or at any later step in this algorithm. For instance, a user agent might wait 500ms or 1024 bytes, whichever came first."

[13:16:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
"Note: The authoring conformance requirements for character encoding declarations limit them to only appearing in the first 1024 bytes. User agents are therefore encouraged to use the preparse algorithm below (part of these steps) on the first 1024 bytes, but not to stall beyond that."

[13:17:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
The upshot is, though, you want to have <meta charset> or whatnot somewhere early in the page.

[13:17:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Having it after lots of prefixes or whatever is definitely bad, it can cause problems.

[13:18:00.0000] <Philip`>
And you want to have HTTP content-type:text/html;charset=utf-8 so browsers don't have to sniff for the encoding at all

[13:18:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or a BOM or something, right.

[13:18:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
But <meta charset> early in the document is also fine.

[13:18:03.0000] <Philip`>
(Having a document specify its encoding in a way that you can only correctly read after decoding the document is a stupid idea :-( )

[13:19:00.0000] <manu-db>
Philip` this is an issue with files on disk... no way to set Content-Type:

[13:19:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, yeah, which is why there's a mini-parser to retrieve <meta charset> . . .

[13:19:02.0000] <The_8472>
how does that parser work?

[13:19:03.0000] <The_8472>
pushing the entire thing through a whole array of charset decoders?

[13:20:00.0000] <Philip`>
The_8472: It's a simplified version of the tokeniser algorithm that looks for meta elements with suitable attributes

[13:20:01.0000] <manu-db>
I'm trying to think of language that we could put in the RDFa Core 1.1 spec that would basically say: "If you want to publish conformant RDFa 1.1 - you should be using UTF-8 and you should be specifying the Content-Type:"

[13:20:02.0000] <Philip`>
and assumes the document is encoded in an ASCII-compatible way

[13:20:03.0000] <The_8472>
ah

[13:21:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
manu-db, note that in HTML5, any document with <meta charset> after the first 1024 bytes is already invalid.

[13:21:01.0000] <The_8472>
so utf-32 would break it

[13:21:02.0000] <Hixie>
utf-32 is strongly discouraged

[13:21:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
So presumably it's already invalid in HTML5+RDFa too.

[13:21:04.0000] <Ms2ger>
Hixie, just discouraged?

[13:21:05.0000] <jamesr>
is utf-32 implemented?

[13:21:06.0000] <manu-db>
We're attempting to constrain @prefix to the root element... and do so in a way that doesn't screw the character encoding detection in browsers.

[13:21:07.0000] <jamesr>
supported?

[13:22:00.0000] <Ms2ger>
