[13:22:01.0000] <Philip`>
I don't the use of UTF-8 is relevant (though it's a good idea anyway) - the default decoding would be win-1252, so UTF-8 is no better than any other encoding in terms of failed charset detection

[13:22:02.0000] <Philip`>
s//think/

[13:22:03.0000] <Hixie>
"Authors should not use UTF-32" and "Support for UTF-32 is not recommended"

[13:23:04.0000] <The_8472>

[13:25:02.0000] <The_8472>

[13:25:03.0000] <zewt>

[13:25:04.0000] <The_8472>

[13:26:00.0000] <zewt>

[13:26:02.0000] <zewt>

[13:27:00.0000] <zewt>

[13:29:00.0000] <Philip`>

[13:30:05.0000] <manu-db>

[13:31:00.0000] <Philip`>

[13:31:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

(Validator developers don't ignore the spec and a non-negligible number of authors don't ignore validators, so I'd assume that's how the spec most influences authors)

[14:12:04.0000] <manu-db>
I don't think just looking at conformance errors are interesting... I think the type of conformance errors are very important.

[14:13:00.0000] <Hixie>
Philip`: right

[14:13:01.0000] <manu-db>
exactly, Philip`

[14:13:02.0000] <Hixie>

[14:13:03.0000] <Hixie>

[14:13:04.0000] <Philip`>

[14:13:05.0000] <Hixie>

[14:13:06.0000] <manu-db>

[14:14:00.0000] <manu-db>

[14:14:01.0000] <Philip`>

[14:14:02.0000] <Philip`>
Any real changes will be drowned out by sampling biases

[14:15:00.0000] <Philip`>
(assuming it was even possible to get historic samples)

[14:15:01.0000] <manu-db>

[14:15:02.0000] <manu-db>
/me wonders if you could crawl the Internet archive for historical samples?

[14:16:00.0000] <manu-db>

[14:16:01.0000] <Philip`>

[14:16:02.0000] <manu-db>

[14:16:03.0000] <manu-db>
and I have no idea why Google wouldn't agree to release those figures publicly.

[14:17:00.0000] <Hixie>

[14:17:01.0000] <manu-db>

[16:32:00.0000] <annevk>
Hixie, btw, what is the difference between EventSource and WebSocket when it comes to garbage collection?

[16:32:01.0000] <annevk>
Hixie, WebSocket is way more complicated

[16:33:00.0000] <Hixie>
the main difference is that websockets speak back to the host

[16:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
also maybe eventsource is buggy? doesn't look like it preserves the object for load/error events...

[16:34:01.0000] <annevk>
e.g. only WebSocket has "make disappear" steps

[16:35:00.0000] <annevk>
EventSource talks about a strong reference instead

[16:35:01.0000] <annevk>
maybe EventSource was done and then later you decided upon another way of doing this?

[16:36:00.0000] <annevk>
I'll file a bug on EventSource so you can take a look, let me know, and maybe I can then finally update XMLHttpRequest

[16:36:01.0000] <Hixie>
the make disappear stuff is entirely because websocket speaks back

[16:37:00.0000] <Hixie>
whereas eventsource is just a one-way connection

[16:37:01.0000] <Hixie>
websockets has a closing handshake, etc

[16:38:00.0000] <annevk>
well eventsource has a request and response

[16:38:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah but it's http, so the connection can just be dropped arbitrarily

[16:38:02.0000] <Hixie>
whereas websocket has this closing handshake thing

[16:38:03.0000] <annevk>
okay

[16:38:04.0000] <annevk>
so XHR should be modeled after EventSource

[16:39:00.0000] <annevk>
I'll file a bug on the other events

[17:16:02.0000] <Philip`>
Scalar ".." is a flip-flop

[17:17:00.0000] <Philip`>

[09:37:00.0000] <jgraham>
The spec is not entirely clear so I am starting to think that I am wrong

[09:38:00.0000] <jgraham>
If an enumerated attribute foo is in the missing value default state and you do x.foo will you get the default value back, or the empty string?

[09:39:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/urls.html#reflecting-content-attributes-in-idl-attributes

[09:39:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
If a reflecting IDL attribute is a DOMString attribute whose content attribute is an enumerated attribute, and the IDL attribute is limited to only known values, then, on getting, the IDL attribute must return the conforming value associated with the state the attribute is in (in its canonical case), or the empty string if the attribute is in a state that has no associated keyword value

[09:39:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
So it depends on whether there's a state associated with the missing value default state.

[09:39:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
The enum stuff is confusing.

[09:41:00.0000] <jgraham>
OK, so in this case it looks like it should return the missing value default

[09:41:01.0000] <jgraham>
So I am wrong

[09:41:02.0000] <jgraham>
But in some other cases I might be right :)

[11:13:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
How easy would it be to write a tool that converts more or less arbitrary HTML5 into polyglot HTML5/XHTML5?

[11:14:00.0000] <Philip`>
Depending on how strictly you interpret "polyglot", probably impossible

[11:14:01.0000] <Philip`>
since you can't use inline scripts

[11:14:02.0000] <Philip`>
and can't use <pre> if the content starts with a blank line

[11:14:03.0000] <Philip`>
etc

[11:37:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, polyglot to the extent of "it more or less looks the same when served as HTML vs. XHTML".

[11:38:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Basically, I'm talking with Ian Jacobs, and he said that the W3C would be okay with allowing specs to be polyglot HTML5, but aren't so sure about regular HTML5.

[11:39:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
So if someone could just throw together a tool that would take the a text/html spec and output a polyglot one that behaves more or less the same, that would be helpful for progress.

[11:39:01.0000] <annevk>
the fuck?

[11:39:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[11:39:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
?

[11:39:04.0000] <AryehGregor>

[11:39:05.0000] <AryehGregor>

[11:39:06.0000] <annevk>

[11:39:07.0000] <AryehGregor>

[11:40:00.0000] <annevk>

[11:40:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[11:40:02.0000] <Ms2ger>
HTML4

[11:40:03.0000] <Philip`>
Just set the HTML serialiser to not omit optional tags and to quote attributes, and stick an xmlns on it, and surely that'll be good enough

[11:41:00.0000] <Philip`>

[11:41:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[11:41:02.0000] <annevk>

[11:42:00.0000] <annevk>

[11:42:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[11:42:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[11:42:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[12:28:00.0000] <manu-db>
Does anybody know the history behind why "application/json" was picked over "text/json" - besides Douglas Crockford's rather cryptic response - "JSON is not really JavaScript and not really text"? Trying to figure out if JSON-LD should have an IANA registration for text/json-ld or application/json-ld or application/json+ld (JSON-LD is 100% compatible w/ JSON)

[12:30:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[12:30:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[12:30:02.0000] <manu-db>

[12:30:03.0000] <manu-db>
s/name/mime type/

[12:31:00.0000] <manu-db>
related browser question: Does any browser actually pay attention to the "+" part of a mime type? For example - "text/xml+xhtml" - do browsers go "oh, that's text/xml" and then go "oh, and it's also xhtml" - or do they just do a regular string comparison for "text/xml+xhtml"?

[12:32:00.0000] <annevk>
it's application/xhtml+xml

[12:32:01.0000] <manu-db>
sorry... that's what I meant.

[12:32:02.0000] <annevk>
and Opera pays special attention to +xml

[12:32:03.0000] <annevk>
not everyone does I believe

[12:32:04.0000] <Ms2ger>
There's an old Gecko bug to do that

[12:32:05.0000] <Ms2ger>
Don't think it's fixed yet

[12:32:06.0000] <annevk>
text/* in general is a flawed media type according to the IETF and therefore they encourage everyone to just use the application/* one

[12:32:07.0000] <manu-db>
just wondering what best practice might be from a browser perspective - application/json-ld or application/json+ld ?

[12:33:00.0000] <annevk>
which of course makes the distinction kind of pointless

[12:33:01.0000] <annevk>
we have been registering various new text/* types following what we think makes sense...

[12:33:02.0000] <annevk>
manu-db, doesn't matter

[12:33:03.0000] <manu-db>
/me nods - there doesn't seem to be a clear logical thread through picking MIMEType names...

[12:34:00.0000] <annevk>
though application/ld+json would make more sense

[12:34:01.0000] <annevk>
or is it not actually JSON?

[12:34:02.0000] <manu-db>

[12:34:03.0000] <manu-db>
it's just JSON in a particular structure.

[12:34:04.0000] <annevk>
then I guess it ought to be +json

[12:35:00.0000] <annevk>
the goal btw is for browsers to treat all XML media types the same way

[12:35:01.0000] <annevk>
as in you can label your XHTML file text/xml and it's fine

[12:35:02.0000] <annevk>
because in practice XML works based on namespaces, not media types

[12:36:00.0000] <manu-db>
one of the reasons I'm shying away from application/ld+json is because there is no such "application/ld" media type... and because I hate plus signs in MIME Types (although, that can't be a basis for any sort of technical decision).

[12:36:01.0000] <annevk>
manu-db, I guess you want application/ld+json so it's consistent with the original JSON (which should have been text/json but isn't) and the +xml precedent

[12:37:00.0000] <annevk>

[12:37:01.0000] <manu-db>

[12:40:00.0000] <Philip`>

[12:41:00.0000] <Philip`>

[12:41:01.0000] <Philip`>

The Open Web Platform is the collection of open (royalty-free) technologies which enables the Web. [16:39:01.0000] <timeless>
this is where a dvcs is useful

[16:39:02.0000] <timeless>
commit changes for person

[16:39:03.0000] <timeless>
commit fixes for changes for person

[16:39:04.0000] <timeless>
commit further fixes for changes for changes...

[16:39:05.0000] <timeless>
merge

[16:39:06.0000] <timeless>
if you need even more changes, you go back to the premerged version and make them there

[16:40:00.0000] <timeless>
and when you want to show someone what you did for them, you can send either the leaf, or the delta between their origin point and their leaf

[16:40:01.0000] <timeless>
(no one does this)

[20:29:00.0000] <heycam>
I'm wondering if there's any reason that the Function interface defined in the spec, which takes (any... args), is used for event handler attributes rather than something that takes say (Event event)

[20:29:01.0000] <heycam>
are there cases where those functions will be invoked with other arguments?

[21:22:00.0000] <Hixie>
heycam: yes, e.g. onerror's arguments array has length 3

[21:23:00.0000] <Hixie>
heycam: also you can pass any function to an event handler attribute, not just one with a single argument

[21:32:00.0000] <heycam>
Hixie, ok. maybe onerror should be a different type? maybe it's not worth it.

[21:33:00.0000] <Hixie>
what practical difference does it make?

[21:33:01.0000] <heycam>
none, just helpers readers of the spec know what type of values are going to be passed to the function

[21:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
*shrug*

[21:34:01.0000] <heycam>
you do have some other callback interface function things in the spec

[21:34:02.0000] <Hixie>
true

[21:34:03.0000] <heycam>
anyway, not important

[15:15:00.0000] <zcorpan>
rfc2397 says it imports "urlchar" from rfc2396, but the string "urlchar" doesn't appear in that document

[15:16:00.0000] <zcorpan>
does it mean "uric"?

[15:35:00.0000] <zcorpan>
ok so with rfc3987's reserved and unreserved chars, minus # and &, we could invent a "base79" encoding for use instead of base64 in data urls

[15:36:00.0000] <zcorpan>
and that still uses ' which could be problematic since then it can't be used in single-quoted values, and there's no char to represent what base64 uses "=" for

[15:38:00.0000] <erlehmann>
zcorpan, why would you do that?

[15:38:01.0000] <zcorpan>
erlehmann: to make it more compactly encoded

[15:39:00.0000] <erlehmann>
(._.)

[16:10:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

Hixie, we discussed undo/redo events, and I think we concluded that we'll just have events along the lines of onbeforecommand and onaftercommand that will fire for things like undo/redo/delete/insertText/etc. whether it's the browser or the user triggering them. [13:48:00.0000] <zcorpan>
so could somebody explain to me what's bad about constants appearing on both the interface object and the prototype?

[13:53:00.0000] <zcorpan>
does ecmascript have a convention for constants?

[13:53:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Dunno.  I suspect the convention is on the interface.

[13:54:00.0000] <zcorpan>
any example?

[13:58:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
For example, the Node interface.

[13:59:00.0000] <zcorpan>
Node was the example used in the thread where constants are on both :)

[13:59:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Heh.

[13:59:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Math.PI

[13:59:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's *just* an interface object, of course.

[13:59:04.0000] <zcorpan>
there's no object implementing Math

[13:59:05.0000] <zcorpan>
yeah

[14:02:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
In IDB, IDBRequest, IDBCursor, and IDBTransaction all put constants on the interface.  The only thing with constants on the object is IDBDatabaseException, which matches the general exception pattern.

[14:03:00.0000] <zcorpan>
doesn't IDB just use webidl to declare its constants?

[14:03:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yeah.

[14:04:00.0000] <zcorpan>
then webidl makes the constants appear on the prototype also

[14:05:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Oh, then I'm confused.  What did you mean by "interface object" if not a WebIDL interface?

[14:06:00.0000] <zcorpan>
"interface object" is defined in webidl

[14:06:01.0000] <zcorpan>
window.Node is an interface object

[14:06:02.0000] <zcorpan>
Node.ELEMENT_NODE is defined and Node.prototype.ELEMENT_NODE is also

[14:07:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Ah, okay.  Then shrug, if you use IDL you just define them on both I guess.

[14:08:00.0000] <zcorpan>
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-script-coord/2011JulSep/0314.html

[14:11:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[06:41:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Is (char)(int)1 a plausible way to check endianness of integers

[06:41:01.0000] <gsnedders>
?

[06:44:00.0000] <jgraham>
gsnedders: Won't the compiler get upset by that?

[06:44:01.0000] <jgraham>
See also http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1001307/detecting-endianness-programmatically-in-a-c-program

[06:44:02.0000] <gsnedders>
(Yay for writing code that depends on endianness)

[06:48:00.0000] <Philip`>
int i = 1; char c[sizeof(int)]; memcpy(c, &i, sizeof(int)); bool is_littleendian = c[0];

[06:49:00.0000] <Philip`>
I'm not sure the union trick is actually legal C (though I'm not sure it's illegal either)

[06:49:01.0000] <Philip`>
but memcpy is always safe

[06:50:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: It's illegal, I'm pretty certain. At least people have managed to cite quite obvious bits of the spec about it.

[06:50:01.0000] <gsnedders>
(Well, it's not illgal, it's just undefined.)

[06:50:02.0000] <Philip`>
(char)(int)1 will always just give you 1, and *(char*)&i will give you bogus results depending on what compiler version and optimisation settings you use

[06:52:00.0000] <Philip`>
(The union thing works in all compilers in practice, though)

[06:52:01.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: Casting to char always take the low-bits?

[06:53:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: bool is C99?

[06:54:00.0000] <jgraham>
/me would imageine without knowing that casting to char does an actual type conversion rather than just reading some subset of the bits

[06:54:01.0000] <gsnedders>
jgraham: What else can it do?

[06:55:00.0000] <gsnedders>
jgraham: a char is just a numberic type

[06:55:01.0000] <gsnedders>
*numeric

[06:55:02.0000] <jgraham>
Well yes, I know that

[06:55:03.0000] <jgraham>
It could overflow differently, for example. And be endianness independent.

[06:56:00.0000] <Philip`>
If char is unsigned, then (char)i adds or subtracts 256 to/from i until it's in the range [0, 255] and then returns that

[06:56:01.0000] <Philip`>
If char is signed, and i is in [0, 255] then it returns that, else it's implementation-defined behaviour

[06:56:02.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: I could remember there was some magic about char, but I couldn't remember what.

[06:57:00.0000] <Philip`>
The magic thing is that you don't know whether it's signed or unsigned

[06:57:01.0000] <gsnedders>
And about casting as well? Which I guess is the adding/subtracting…

[06:58:00.0000] <Philip`>
(bool isn't in C99; use a BOOL or int or whatever, or use C++)

[06:59:00.0000] <Philip`>
In C99, casting is the same process for any integer types (except _Bool)

[06:59:01.0000] <Philip`>
...except replace "256" by appropriate values etc

[07:00:00.0000] <tomasf>
according to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stdbool.h , bool expands to _Bool in C99

[07:00:01.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: (Yeah, I know what to do)

[07:01:00.0000] <Philip`>
Basically it always does the mathematically obvious thing, except it's unwilling to assume two's-complement representation so any cases of signed overflow are implementation-defined behaviour

[07:02:00.0000] <Philip`>
and it's all endian-independent until you try to read the char representation of a larger value

[07:03:00.0000] <Philip`>
But in any case, it's usually more useful to know endianness at compile-time and not run-time

[07:04:00.0000] <gsnedders>
so reading an int into a short is endian dependent, assuming they're different sizes?

[07:04:01.0000] <Philip`>
since then you can have byte-swap macros that get replaced with noops

[07:04:02.0000] <Philip`>
so you should have a configure script or something to detect it and set a macro

[07:04:03.0000] <Philip`>
What do you mean by "reading into"?

[07:05:00.0000] <gsnedders>
*read the short representation of an int

[07:08:00.0000] <Philip`>
What do you mean by that?

[07:08:01.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: (But yes, it makes sense to do this in a saner way once I have all the setup to do that, which is pretty much going to be when I stop playing around with this code as a standalone application

[07:08:02.0000] <Philip`>
(Values have byte repesentations, not short representations)

[07:09:00.0000] <gsnedders>
/me wants to give up on IRC as this internet connection isn't working well

[07:09:01.0000] <gsnedders>
/me is on the WCML being all fancy and stuff in first-class, because Bank Holiday Monday => cheap upgrades.

[07:16:00.0000] <Philip`>
In practice, the solution that works 99.99% of the time is "#define IS_LITTLE_ENDIAN 1"

[07:18:00.0000] <gsnedders>
That's effectively what this code already is. :)

[09:08:00.0000] <zcorpan>
hey, a spambug reported from http://html5.clearboth.org/spec !

[09:11:00.0000] <timeless>
anyone here have some time to consider some Web IDL?

[09:12:00.0000] <timeless>
X implements Y;

[09:12:01.0000] <timeless>
interface Y: Z;

[09:12:02.0000] <timeless>
Z implements P;

[09:12:03.0000] <timeless>
the contents of the interfaces are omited for brevity and the names have been changed to protect the guilty

[09:13:00.0000] <zcorpan>
the question is?

[09:14:00.0000] <timeless>
err lemme make sure i got that last line right

[09:14:01.0000] <timeless>
yeah, i did

[09:14:02.0000] <timeless>
well, first of all, is one really supposed to be using `implements` on interfaces which are inherited by other interfaces?

[09:14:03.0000] <timeless>
/me thought that `implements` was generally for objects and not interfaces

[09:16:00.0000] <timeless>
note to self: send feedback to list requesting a line "Generally you should use `dictionary Foo` instead of `[NoInterfaceObject] interface Foo`."

[09:17:00.0000] <zcorpan>
yeah implements might be a bad word

[09:18:00.0000] <zcorpan>
though i don't see what's wrong with using it on interfaces that are inherited

[09:21:00.0000] <timeless>
well

[09:21:01.0000] <timeless>
the problem is this:

[09:21:02.0000] <timeless>
ConcreteObject A;

[09:21:03.0000] <timeless>
A implements IFoo;

[09:21:04.0000] <timeless>
A implements IBar;

[09:21:05.0000] <timeless>
A implements IBaz;

[09:21:06.0000] <timeless>
ConcreteObject B;

[09:21:07.0000] <timeless>
B implements IFoo;

[09:22:00.0000] <timeless>
if someone decides that they have a `B` and want to make B's IFoo interface do more

[09:22:01.0000] <timeless>
they might say:

[09:22:02.0000] <timeless>
IFoo implements IMyFooMore;

[09:22:03.0000] <timeless>
expecting it to make B more powerful

[09:22:04.0000] <timeless>
but at the same time, it causes random effects on A

[09:22:05.0000] <timeless>
note that we had this experience in mozilla land

[09:22:06.0000] <timeless>
the rule which we try to enforce is this:

[09:23:00.0000] <timeless>
Only the owner of IFoo is allowed to extend IFoo until IFoo is frozen, at which point, IFoo /may/ but probably /should not/ be extended by others

[09:24:00.0000] <timeless>
roughly that translates into `You, owner of ConcreteObject X are free to use 'X implements IWhatever;'

[09:24:01.0000] <timeless>
but you are not free to use 'IStandardsBodyThing implements IWhatever;'.`

[15:23:00.0000] <smaug____>
AryehGregor: ping

[15:23:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
smaug____, pong.

[15:23:02.0000] <smaug____>
AryehGregor: about http://html5.org/specs/dom-range.html#range-behavior-under-document-mutation and splitText

[15:24:00.0000] <smaug____>
what if textnode's parent is null

[15:24:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Don't I handle that explicitly?

[15:24:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
"If old node's parent is not null, . . ."

[15:24:03.0000] <smaug____>
AryehGregor: you handle not-null case

[15:24:04.0000] <smaug____>
but where is the is null

[15:25:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
That's a corner case, so nothing special happens.  Regular range mutation rules apply.

[15:25:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
IIRC I used to handle it, but decided it was pointless to worry about it.

[15:25:02.0000] <smaug____>
hmm

[15:25:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Often you can't do better than the default behavior anyway.

[15:25:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Since the range can't span the two text nodes.

[15:25:05.0000] <smaug____>
AryehGregor: so what if you split text between the boundary points

[15:26:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
If the parent is null?  Exactly what Gecko does now: any boundary point after the offset you're splitting at is clamped to the end of the node.

[15:26:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
There's no special case then.

[15:27:00.0000] <smaug____>
ah

[15:27:01.0000] <smaug____>
ok

[15:27:02.0000] <smaug____>
a bit hard to read but ok

[15:27:03.0000] <smaug____>
I mean the draft

[15:28:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
What wording would you suggest?

[15:29:00.0000] <smaug____>
well, I was assuming that since there is the "If old node's parent is not null" case, there would be also the "is null" case

[15:30:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Would you assume that when reading code?  If it doesn't give the case, it's not there.

[15:30:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
This is really just pseudocode.

[15:30:02.0000] <smaug____>
well, there is the other case defined

[15:30:03.0000] <smaug____>
"User agents must run the following steps whenever they execute splitText()"

[15:31:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Right, just sometimes they do nothing.  Of course, the horrible way this is written is a hack to work around the fact that we haven't merged it into DOM Core yet.

[15:31:01.0000] <smaug____>
well, they need to update the boundary points when parent is null

[15:31:02.0000] <smaug____>
that is not "do nothing"

[15:32:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's "do nothing extra".

[15:32:01.0000] <smaug____>
the draft doesn't say that do something, but when splitText() is called, do something extra

[15:33:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
It says UAs have to run the steps as though they were written at the end of splitText().

[15:33:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Earlier than that, splitText() replaced data and probably inserted a node.

[15:33:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
That already triggered different mutation rules.

[15:33:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
I have a note there that points this out explicitly: "Thus they must be executed after following the range mutation rules for any changes to data or insertions that the method caused."

[15:34:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Also, one of the steps is "Let original offset equal what the boundary point's offset was before this splitText invocation replaced the data of node."  That doesn't make any sense if you didn't already have range mutation rules running beforehand.

[15:34:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I'd ask for suggestions to make this clearer, but it will be moot once it's merged into DOM Core.

[15:35:00.0000] <smaug____>
a lot clearer would be to add just the case for null parent

[15:35:01.0000] <smaug____>
or at least a link

[15:36:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
A link to what?

[15:36:01.0000] <smaug____>
to the part of the spec which says what to do when parent is null

[15:36:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
You do nothing extra when the parent is null.

[15:37:00.0000] <smaug____>
this is about readability of the spec

[15:37:01.0000] <smaug____>
not correctness

[15:37:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Readability is a mess because it's trying to hack extra steps onto DOM Core when DOM Core doesn't provide hooks for it.

[15:37:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
This will be solved when DOM Range is merged into DOM Core, so this will just be an extra step or two in the splitText() algorithm itself.

even far to be a niche problem… it's one of the first questions I get when talking about mediaqueries for background images. "OH cool!!! How can I use it for img too?"

[08:36:00.0000] <zewt>

[08:39:00.0000] <zewt>

[08:39:01.0000] <karlcow>

[08:40:00.0000] <karlcow>

[08:40:01.0000] <zewt>
screen size is meaningless without dpi as well

[08:41:00.0000] <zewt>

[08:41:01.0000] <zewt>

[08:42:00.0000] <karlcow>

[08:43:00.0000] <zewt>

[08:44:00.0000] <karlcow>

[08:46:00.0000] <zewt>

[08:47:00.0000] <zewt>
so it could download however much is needed for the resolution it's actually displaying at (and then resume the download to get more, if that changes)

[08:50:00.0000] <annevk>
karlcow, if you are already talking in the context of images it's not surprising the question comes up

[08:50:01.0000] <karlcow>
annevk: not sure how does it relate to what we are saying.

[08:50:02.0000] <karlcow>
contextual images is a **need**, not a niche problem, and a growing frustration from designers.

[08:50:03.0000] <karlcow>
it is already implemented and well used for background-images in CSS

[08:50:04.0000] <karlcow>
people want it for img element

[08:51:00.0000] <annevk>
what's wrong with using a high-resolution image?

[08:51:01.0000] <karlcow>
It has nothing to do with the resolution

[08:53:00.0000] <karlcow>
for example, contextual images are an image where you would have a "Logo + company name" (let's say a 400 pixels banner) then when you reach a smaller screen, you want to display only the logo without the company name, (like a 100px square logo)

[08:53:01.0000] <karlcow>
It is just an example.

[08:54:00.0000] <karlcow>
a thumbnail of an image at a small size is not necessary the full image but a crop of the bigger image.

[08:54:01.0000] <zewt>
i'd think you'd just have two images in that case, toggled on mutually exclusively with css, not a single image with src magic

[08:54:02.0000] <karlcow>
like for example a rectangle image and you show a square crop at smaller size

[08:54:03.0000] <karlcow>
etc etc

[08:54:04.0000] <karlcow>
zewt: you are not forced to limit yourself to two images

[08:55:00.0000] <zewt>
yes, you can have three or four images, again with visibility controlled with css :)

[08:55:01.0000] <karlcow>
because you can precisely target a very large screen, a tablet screen, a giant billboard, a desktop screen, etc.

[08:55:02.0000] <zewt>
(not ideal, since it won't work well if the stylesheet isn't loaded, but "css is optional" doesn't exactly work in practice very often anyway heh)

[08:55:03.0000] <shetech>
/me thinks this would be great for targeting mobile vs. full screen

[08:58:00.0000] <zewt>
karlcow: what i'm saying is, why do this with a complex <img> mechanism, instead of implementing it with multiple, distinct <img> nodes, controlling visibility on each (whether with css or otherwise)

[08:59:00.0000] <annevk>

[15:43:00.0000] <karlcow>
AryehGregor: before I say more stupid things on the list, let me check here. ;) could the renameElement thing be used to feed the browser with "<foo><bar/></foo>" and then transform it into the DOM as "<p><img/></p>"

[16:03:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
karlcow: Yes, but it would be a really dumb and fragile thing to do.

[16:06:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
karlcow: You'd have to iterate through the entire document, transforming every individual element.  If JS failed, you'd just have a giant bag of unknown elements that styling wouldn't work on.  Even when JS worked, you'd get significant and unavoidable flashes of unstyled content (multiple, because each swap would almost certainly trigger relayout).

[16:35:00.0000] <karlcow>
TabAtkins: thanks a lot

[16:36:00.0000] <karlcow>
for the dumbness ;) I'm always surprised by what people try to do online ;)

[04:14:01.0000] <annevk>

[08:26:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[08:27:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, DOM operations never trigger repaints.  Repaints only happen when the event loop spins.  Except in Opera, which is broken.

[08:27:01.0000] <annevk>
"broken"

[08:28:00.0000] <jgraham>
Hmm, why is that broken?

[08:28:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Because it will display transient states to the user.

[08:28:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Also, it's different from every other browser, which is broken more or less by default.

[08:28:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
I saw someone from Opera say it caused site compat issues, IIRC.

[08:29:00.0000] <jgraham>
Displaying transient states to the user is normal

[08:29:01.0000] <jgraham>
Think progressive loading

[08:29:02.0000] <timeless>
asmodai: i'm fairly certain ocsp checks are cached

[08:29:03.0000] <asmodai>
timeless: That would explain then

[08:29:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Depends on your definition of "transient".

[08:29:05.0000] <jgraham>
It can cause slowness if you don't carefully control how often you repaint ofc

[08:29:06.0000] <annevk>
it causes uglyness indeed mostly because other browsers have a silly blocking implementation

[08:30:00.0000] <annevk>
and authors authored against the silly implementations

[08:30:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
In Opera's implementation, there's no way to have the browser not display a half-mutated DOM.  It will display some snapshot at random depending on when it decides to repaint.

[08:31:00.0000] <jgraham>
Roughly the same as every browser and loading off the network really

[08:31:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
As opposed to other browsers, which will never display anything unless the event loop spins, so a bunch of consecutive operations will always be run atomically from the user's perspective.

[08:31:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Loading off the network is a special case.

[08:31:03.0000] <jgraham>
But there's no intrinsic reason it has to be

[08:31:04.0000] <jgraham>
If you have a very slow running script, displaying something is better than displaying nothing

[08:32:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yes, if it's slow-running enough, maybe.

[08:32:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Particularly if you try to be intelligent about which point to display.

[08:32:02.0000] <jgraham>
That is often the case on lower end devices

[12:13:00.0000] <Philip`>

[12:13:01.0000] <timeless>

[12:14:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, I'd say that draconian enforcement of quoted attributes is fine, but matched tags is already dodgy.  It means well-formedness isn't local.  It's common to want to stitch together a bunch of elements with the start and end tags added in separate places.

[12:15:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
But it's very rare you want to output an attribute other than all at once, so it's relatively easy to vet for well-formedness.

[12:15:01.0000] <timeless>
> Also, conforming trees that have tr elements as children of table elements will be replaced with semantically equivalent but tree-wise different construct where the tr elements gain a tbody parent which is a child of the table.

[12:15:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
MediaWiki has known cases where its parser misnests tags in output, which are very hard to fix, but attribute quoting is just fine.

[14:24:00.0000] <timeless>

[14:37:00.0000] <timeless>
it also seems relatively clear that one is unlikely to generally want a list of all arcs which compose a forest

[14:37:01.0000] <timeless>
since most of them will be overlapped by other things and are thus irrelevant to you or anyone who would be at your perspective

[14:38:00.0000] <timeless>
anyway

[14:39:00.0000] <timeless>
it seems that in the end, if someone is going to design something for people who need accessibility support, they will need to ensure that the widgets they provide aren't ambiguous and have sufficient detail to indicate what would happen if they were poked

[14:39:01.0000] <timeless>
a button labeled "button" would thus fail, especially if it were next to 4 others with the same label..

[14:40:00.0000] <timeless>
whereas buttons labeled "floodfill", "stamp", "line", "erase" wouldn't have such a problem, and one wouldn't necessarily need to care where they are so long as one could discover they exist..

[14:41:00.0000] <timeless>
/me has a feeling that a lot of this is already addressed by ARIA's ability to list areas which are subject to change, and identify changes

[16:40:01.0000] <Moo^_^>
jacobolus: I want to use images from another domain, but not tainting the canvas

[16:40:02.0000] <Moo^_^>
need to mash up images from two different sources

[16:41:00.0000] <roc>
there is CORS for images now

[16:41:01.0000] <roc>
see the "crossorigin" attribute

[16:41:02.0000] <roc>
only implemented in latest versions of Chrome and Firefox AFAIK

[16:41:03.0000] <zewt>
yeah, CORS already does that, for webgl

[16:44:00.0000] <Philip`>
Moo^_^: Tainting is based on origins, which are scheme+host+port

[16:45:00.0000] <Philip`>
so changing port is the same as changing host

[16:45:01.0000] <Moo^_^>
roc: zewt: Philip`: Thanks a lot!
